question: Why do Nasa launch rockets from sea level instead of from the top of a mountain if they launch from a higher point they will need less fuel because they have to go a shorter distance , right ? Please explain like I'm five.

Launching a rocket from the top of a mountain would be very difficult because the mountain would need to be tall enough and stable enough to support the weight of the rocket and all of its equipment. It would also be hard to build the infrastructure needed for the launch at the top of a mountain. 
Additionally, launching a rocket from sea level, where the air is denser, can actually be more efficient because it allows the rocket to take advantage of the Earth's atmosphere to gain additional speed. When you connect to a WiFi network, you are connecting to a specific network that is broadcasting on a particular frequency band, and the router that is broadcasting that network is responsible for managing the data that is transmitted over that network. 
In order to combine two or more WiFi networks, you would need a way to connect all of the routers together and merge their frequency bands into a single network. question: People with liver disease have a unique smell . What is it ? I can walk into a room and smell that my brother was just there . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Most veins lead towards venae cavae ( the big veins in your torso that lead directly into the heart ) but there 's a system of veins ( known as portal veins ) that go from your intestines to your liver instead for detoxification and storage of nutrients . Then the blood continues on to the inferior vena cava . Blood ca n't flow as easily through a cirrhosed liver so it gets backed up and eventually is forced backwards into the rest of the circulatory system , normally through some veins around the lower oesophagus ( your food pipe ) and the stomach . This way you end up with blood going from your intestines ( carrying normal dissolved chemicals from your food ) to the general circulation without the liver ever cleaning it up , so to speak . Some of these chemicals end up in the lungs and are breathed out , like how when your blood has alcohol in it some of it comes out in your breath ( which is how breathalysers work and how we can smell when someone is really drunk ) . The technical term is foetor hepaticus and a main chemical compounds responsible are suspected to be dimethyl sulfide , found in several vegetables , and thiols or mercaptans , which are the chemicals added to natural gas to give it a distinctive smell .

question: open vs closed back headphones . What are the advantages and disadvantages for them and which ones are used for what ? Edit : thanks to everyone who took the time . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Open-back headphones have a design where the ear cups are not sealed and allow sound to pass through them. This can give a more natural and open sound, as if you are listening to speakers in a room rather than headphones on your head. The sound from open-back headphones may also be more spacious and have a wider soundstage, which can be beneficial for certain types of music and audio recording. 
On the other hand, closed-back headphones have a design where the ear cups are sealed and do not allow sound to pass through them. This can provide a more isolated listening experience and can be helpful for blocking out external noise. Closed-back headphones are often preferred for noisy environments or for use in situations where you do not want others to hear what you are listening to. They are also often used for monitoring in recording studios, as they can help to prevent sound leakage into microphones. 
Both open-back and closed-back headphones have their own advantages and disadvantages, and which one is best for you will depend on your specific needs and preferences. Some people prefer open-back headphones for their natural sound, while others prefer closed-back headphones for their isolation and ability to block out external noise. Ultimately, it comes down to personal preference and the specific use case.

question: Why do we close our eyes when we sleep ? In debth biology explanation :) Please explain like I'm five.

When we are awake and our eyes are open, we blink to keep our eyes moist and to wash away any dirt or dust that might have gotten into them. However, when we are asleep, we don't blink as much, so closing our eyes helps to keep our eyes moist and protected. 
Another reason we close our eyes when we sleep is to help our brain relax. When we are awake, our eyes are constantly sending signals to our brain about what we are seeing. These signals can be distracting and make it harder for us to relax and fall asleep. By closing our eyes, we block out these signals and give our brain a chance to rest and recharge. 
Finally, closing our eyes can help us to feel more comfortable and cozy when we are sleeping. It can be nice to have a sense of darkness and privacy when we are in bed, and closing our eyes helps to create this feeling. 
So, to summarize, we close our eyes when we sleep to protect our eyes, to help our brain relax, and to feel more comfortable and cozy.

There are a few reasons why Apple decided to use the Lightning connector instead of micro-USB. One reason is that the Lightning connector is smaller and more compact than micro-USB, which allows it to be used on devices with smaller form factors, such as the iPhone. Additionally, the Lightning connector is reversible, which means it can be plugged in either way, making it easier to use. 
Another reason is that the Lightning connector is able to transmit data as well as power, which means that it can be used to connect devices to a computer for transferring files, or to connect to other devices for things like audio or video output. Overall, the decision to use the Lightning connector was made by Apple in order to give them more control over the design and functionality of their devices, and to offer features that are not possible with micro-USB.

question: What is silica gel ? What does it do and how does it kill you ? I see so many of these in the warehouse inside shipping boxes . I 'm just so curious Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Silica gel is a small, hard, porous bead made of silicon dioxide. It is often used as a desiccant, which means it absorbs moisture from the air. Desiccants are used to help prevent things from getting damp or moist, which can cause them to spoil, rust, or become moldy. 
Silica gel is often used in shipping boxes to help keep the contents dry during transportation. It can also be found in products like shoe boxes and food packaging to help extend the shelf life of the products. 
Silica gel is not toxic and is not dangerous to humans. However, it is not meant to be eaten, so it is important to keep it away from children and pets. Swallowing large amounts of silica gel can cause digestive problems, so it is best to avoid swallowing it. 
Overall, silica gel is a useful and safe product that helps to keep things dry and prevent damage or spoilage.

question: How can cell phones and other electronic devices tell how much battery life they have left . do batteries put off more energy when full ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Most electronic devices, including cell phones, use lithium-ion batteries, which have a built-in mechanism for keeping track of their charge level. Inside the battery, there are tiny electrical components called "charge coulometers" that keep track of the amount of charge going in and out of the battery. 
When the battery is being charged, the coulometers measure the amount of charge going into the battery and store this information. When the battery is being used to power the device, the coulometers measure the amount of charge being used and update the stored information accordingly. 
The device's battery meter then uses this stored information to display the current charge level on the device's screen. So, the battery doesn't actually "put off" more energy when it is full. Instead, it is the coulometers inside the battery that keep track of the charge level and let the device know how much battery life is left.

question: How does an electronic device that tells the time know what time it is after it has been off ? When your phone / computer or whatever has been off for a while , how does it know the time once its been on ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Most electronic devices that tell the time, like phones and computers, have a small battery inside them that powers a tiny chip called a "real-time clock" (RTC). The RTC chip is responsible for keeping track of the time even when the device is turned off. 
When the device is turned on, it uses the time stored on the RTC chip to set the time on the device's display. The device may also connect to the internet and check with an online server to get the most accurate time possible. This helps to ensure that the time displayed on the device is accurate, even if the device has been off for a long time.

question: How is body fat " burned " off during excercise ? I 've heard something about fat is expelled as CO2 when you breath out but I do n't fully understand the whole process . Anyone know how it works ? Please explain like I'm five.

The chemical reaction looks like this : Fat + O2 - > H2O + CO2 So , you 're body takes in oxygen when you breathe . That oxygen reacts with the fat molecule , that has hydrogen , oxygen and carbon to form carbon dioxide and water .

question: How is body fat " burned " off during excercise ? I 've heard something about fat is expelled as CO2 when you breath out but I do n't fully understand the whole process . Anyone know how it works ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When you exercise, your body uses stored energy in the form of fat to fuel your muscles. Your body has a limited amount of energy stored in the form of glycogen (a type of carbohydrate) in your muscles and liver, and when that runs out, it turns to fat as an energy source. 
Here's how it works: 
1. When you start exercising, your body breaks down glycogen stored in your muscles and liver into glucose (a type of sugar) to use for energy. 
2. As you continue to exercise, your body uses up more and more glycogen and starts to use fat as an energy source. 
3. When your body uses fat for energy, it breaks down the fat molecules into smaller parts, including glycerol and fatty acids. 
4. The glycerol and fatty acids are then taken to your cells, where they are used to produce energy through a process called cellular respiration. 
5. During cellular respiration, oxygen is used to convert the glycerol and fatty acids into energy, and carbon dioxide (CO2) and water are produced as byproducts. 
6. The CO2 is expelled from your body when you breathe out, and the water is expelled through urine and sweat. 
So, to answer your question, when you exercise, your body burns fat by using it for energy and releasing the byproducts (CO2 and water) through your breath, urine, and sweat.

question: Why do people disagree with stem cell research ? am i missing something here ? ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Two reasons : 1 ) Often because their understanding is poor , and scientists often do a horrible job of explaining . Many people think embryonic stem cells from abortions , which is incorrect . In fact they come in - vitro fertilisation ( i.e. artificially injecting donated eggs with sperm ) . When couples go for IVF , because they can not conceive naturally scientists fertilise several eggs ( usually around 20 ) in a dish . Obviously nobody wants to be implanted with 20 fertilised eggs , so there are spares left over . They would either go in the bin , or they can be used for research . That 's where scientists get their stem cells from . Embryonic stem cells are only present during very early stages after the sperm fertilises the egg . This is called the blastocyst . If this was taking place inside a woman , she would NOT be pregnant at this stage . A woman is only pregnant after the fertilised egg implants into the uterus wall . Thus , embryonic stem cells are not in any way related to abortions . 2 ) Technically , a fertilised egg * could * be considered as the start of life . The egg carries one set of chromosomes ( 23 ) , and the sperm carries the other ( 23 ) . So when fertilisation takes place and the chromosomes combine ( giving you 2x 23 chromosomes ) and the cell divides , this technically is a brand new combination - an individual - i.e. all of the genetic instructions required create a unique human being . So it 's fair to say that by harvesting stem cells ( thus destroying that embryo ) , you are removing all potential for life . However , it 's worth saying that without implanting into the uterus wall , development into a foetus would never have been possible . So IMO there is one ridiculous argument , and one realistic one .

question: Why does it not lightning during a snowstorm ? But why is it less common then ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Lightning is caused by the buildup of static electricity in the clouds. This can occur during a snowstorm, but it is less common because snow is made up of small, lightweight ice crystals that do not produce as much static electricity as other types of precipitation, such as rain or hail. 
When it is cold and dry outside, the air is less able to hold moisture, which can cause snowflakes to form. As these snowflakes fall through the air, they rub against each other and can build up a static charge. However, this charge is not strong enough to produce lightning, which requires a much larger buildup of static electricity. 
In contrast, rain and hail are made up of larger, heavier water droplets that are more effective at producing static electricity. When it is warm and humid outside, the air can hold more moisture, which can cause rain and hail to form. These larger water droplets are more effective at rubbing against each other and building up a static charge, which can lead to lightning. 
So, while it is possible for lightning to occur during a snowstorm, it is less common because snow is not as effective at producing static electricity as other types of precipitation.

question: Why is it that the worst type of murder is " first degree " whereas the worst type of burn is " third degree " ? Why the opposite ? Please explain like I'm five.

The terms "first degree" and "third degree" are used to describe the severity of different types of injuries. They are not used to describe the severity of crimes. 
In the context of burns, "first degree burns" are the least severe. They usually affect only the outer layer of skin and cause redness, pain, and swelling. "Second degree burns" are more severe and affect the outer layer of skin and the layer underneath. They can cause blistering and are more painful than first degree burns. "Third degree burns" are the most severe. They damage all layers of the skin and can even damage the tissues underneath. Third degree burns can be very serious and require medical attention. 
In the context of murder, "first degree murder" is considered the most serious because it involves premeditation and planning. It is the intentional and premeditated killing of another person. "Second degree murder" is also a serious crime, but it does not involve the same level of planning and intent as first degree murder. It is the intentional killing of another person, but without premeditation. "Third degree murder" is generally considered the least serious of the three degrees of murder. It is the unintentional killing of another person while committing a non-violent crime. 
So, the terms "first degree" and "third degree" are used to describe different levels of severity, but they are used in opposite ways depending on the context.

question: Why do n't US citizens vote directly on all legislation ? In lieu of voting for people who may or may not vote on the voter 's behalf . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Most of it is historical reasoning : America was founded as a representative democracy , primarily because the Founding Fathers did n't exactly trust the general public on being educated enough on every issue to vote . So they trusted them to vote on representatives who shared similar views , but would be educated enough to actually know what 's best . Those representatives are then the ones who directly vote for laws . Second reasoning is also important : under what system would people vote directly on laws ? Switzerland does it , more or less , because their country is the size of postage stamp ( apologies to any Swiss people ) compared to the United States . This was more or less impossible for the better part of American history , considering the founding of America predated the internet , or even telegraph lines . It 's difficult even now ; yes the internet may provide an avenue , but considering how we had trouble building a healthcare website , do you really think the government can build a website for voting ? And then we run into the problem of actual legislation voting : legislation is more than the things we hear about in news ( like the Affordable Care Act ) . There is important federal laws , but then there are state laws , but then there are individual counties within states too . Considering the dense amount of material that needs to be read and decided upon ( ordinances , laws , taxes , amendments ) , it 's simpler to divide each level by different government levels and have ( informed and trained ) representatives to decide for us .

question: Why do n't US citizens vote directly on all legislation ? In lieu of voting for people who may or may not vote on the voter 's behalf . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
In the United States, citizens do not vote directly on legislation because the country has a representative democracy. This means that citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf, including voting on legislation. 
The idea behind this system is that it allows for a more efficient way to make decisions. If every citizen had to vote on every piece of legislation, it would be very time-consuming and would likely result in less effective decision-making. By electing representatives to make these decisions, the government is able to move more quickly and effectively. 
Additionally, representatives are able to consider the needs and opinions of their constituents (the people they represent) when they make decisions. This means that they can take into account the views of their constituents when they vote on legislation. 
Overall, the representative democracy system allows for a more efficient and effective way to make decisions and ensure that the needs and opinions of the people are taken into account.

question: What exactly does a PC cleanup do ? My PC could use some cleanup . I 'm just wondering what happens exactly in a standard PC cleaning . Thanks in advance ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
A PC cleanup is a process that involves removing unnecessary files and programs from your computer to free up storage space and improve its performance. Here are the steps that are typically involved in a standard PC cleaning: 
1. Uninstalling unnecessary programs: You can go to the "Control Panel" on your PC and look for programs that you no longer use or need. You can then select these programs and uninstall them to free up space on your hard drive. 
2. Removing temporary files: Temporary files are created by your operating system and various programs when they run. These files are not needed after the program has finished running, and they can take up a lot of space on your hard drive. You can use the "Disk Cleanup" tool on your PC to remove these temporary files. 
3. Emptying the recycle bin: The recycle bin is a folder on your computer where deleted files are stored until you decide to permanently delete them. Emptying the recycle bin will free up more space on your hard drive. 
4. Defragmenting your hard drive: When you use your computer, the data on your hard drive gets scattered across different locations. Defragmenting your hard drive involves organizing the data so that it is stored in a more efficient way, which can improve the performance of your computer. 
5. Updating your operating system: Keeping your operating system up to date can help fix any bugs or security vulnerabilities and improve the overall performance of your computer. 
6. Running a virus scan: A virus scan involves using antivirus software to search for and remove any malware (viruses, worms, Trojans, etc.) that may be present on your computer. This can help protect your computer from security threats and improve its performance. 
Doing these things can help make your computer run faster and more smoothly. It's a good idea to do a PC cleanup every once in a while to keep your computer in good shape.

question: Why have humans evolved so far as to lose their thick coats but still grow hair on their heads and faces ? What purpose does it have ? Just confused as to why we all still grow hair if it does n't really do anything . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: In short because as humans evolved from arboreal dwelling primates to plains dwelling proto humans it was more important to keep cool , and since we sweat to keep cool those who were less hairy tended to cool off better and hence survive better to pass on the less hairy genes . Hair on the top of the head remained because it was likely an effective sun block , and pubic hair probably had some part in sexual attraction or scent retention . Humans in this environment had dark skin pigmentation that evolved as a natural sun block as hair was lost . Once humans began expanding to cooler climates they had learned to use animal skins , and hairy individuals did n't survive any better than less hairy ones , so humans who moved to cold climates did n't have to be hairy to pass on their genes . Edit : Also around 10,000 years ago , give or take , humans in colder climates who 's skin had less pigmentation were more able to make use the decreased sunlight , and eventually the lighter skin became the predominate skin tone in these climates .

question: Why have humans evolved so far as to lose their thick coats but still grow hair on their heads and faces ? What purpose does it have ? Just confused as to why we all still grow hair if it does n't really do anything . Please explain like I'm five.

Human beings have evolved over many thousands of years, and the way our bodies look and function today is the result of a long process of natural selection. Over time, this can lead to changes in the way that a species looks and functions. 
One of the ways that human beings have adapted to their environment is by losing the thick coat of fur that many other mammals have. This may have happened because human beings developed the ability to make and wear clothing, which provided protection from the elements and allowed them to live in a wider range of environments. 
At the same time, human beings still have hair on their heads and faces. This hair serves several purposes. For example, the hair on our heads helps to keep us warm and provides some protection from the sun. The hair on our faces, particularly in men, may have evolved to signal social and sexual maturity, as well as to protect the face from injury. 
So, in short, the reason why human beings have evolved to lose their thick coats but still grow hair on their heads and faces is because these features have helped us to adapt to our environment and survive as a species.

question: what are the ACTUAL ingredients in a vaccine , and what are their purposes ? I 've read everything from mercury to aborted fetal tissue , what 's the real story ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: The essential ingredient is a small amount of the thing you 're trying to vaccinate against . Usually , it 's either a mild or a disabled form of the pathogen ( " thing that makes you sick " ) that wo n't put up a good fight to the immune system . The immune system , in turn , learns what that pathogen looks like and can fight it better later - sort of the same principle as training a dog to recognize a smell . All the other stuff is there to help that successfully get into your body . The " mercury " that anti - vaxxers panic about is a preservative called thiomersal , which is there to prevent bacteria from growing inside the vaccine dose . Since it 's to be shot directly into your bloodstream , it would be bad to have a large enough dose there to make you sick . Thiomersal is , as far as we know , safe in the tiny amounts used in vaccines , but it 's no longer used in most of them anyway . The fetal tissue I would assume is used as a growth medium , but that strikes me as a " YOU'RE INJECTING DEAD BABIES!!!11!!ONE!!111 " panic thing .

question: what are the ACTUAL ingredients in a vaccine , and what are their purposes ? I 've read everything from mercury to aborted fetal tissue , what 's the real story ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Vaccines are made up of a few different ingredients that are combined to help prevent diseases. Here are some of the common ingredients you might find in a vaccine, and what they do: 
1. Antigens: These are the parts of the virus or bacteria that the vaccine is designed to protect against. The vaccine will contain a small amount of the virus or bacteria, or a part of it, to help your body build immunity to it. 
2. Adjuvants: These are substances that are added to the vaccine to help boost your body's response to the vaccine. They help your body create more antibodies, which are proteins that help fight off infections. 
3. Preservatives: These are added to the vaccine to help prevent contamination and keep the vaccine safe for use. One common preservative is thimerosal, which contains mercury. However, it is important to note that the mercury in thimerosal is in a form that is not harmful to humans. 
4. Stabilizers: These are added to the vaccine to help keep it stable and effective over time. 
5. Inactivating agents: These are added to vaccines made from viruses to help kill the virus so it can't cause disease. 
It's important to note that vaccines do not contain any whole, viable viruses or bacteria, and they do not contain any fetal tissue. Vaccines are rigorously tested and are safe and effective at preventing diseases. They have saved countless lives and are an important tool in public health.

question: What 's so great about an Ivy League school versus a state school ? Besides the fact that Ivy League schools are older . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Ivy League schools are considered to be some of the most prestigious universities in the United States. They are known for their strong academic programs, distinguished faculty, and successful graduates. These schools tend to have smaller class sizes, more resources, and a greater emphasis on research than many state schools. 
One of the main reasons that Ivy League schools are considered so prestigious is because they have very selective admissions processes. This means that only a small percentage of students who apply are accepted, which makes it difficult to get in. As a result, students who attend Ivy League schools are often among the most talented and motivated in the country. 
State schools, on the other hand, are publicly funded institutions that are open to anyone who meets their admissions requirements. They tend to have larger class sizes and may not have as many resources as Ivy League schools, but they can still offer a high-quality education. Some state schools are also very prestigious and competitive, and many students who attend these schools go on to successful careers. 
In summary, Ivy League schools are known for their prestige, strong academics, and selective admissions processes, while state schools are generally more accessible and may not have as many resources. Both types of schools can provide a good education, and the choice between them ultimately depends on the individual student's needs and goals.

question: What are the potential dangers of AI ? There is much talk lately that AI poses a huge risk to the future of humanity . What are the possible worst case scenarios and how might it affect humanity if it all goes wrong ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are many potential dangers associated with artificial intelligence (AI), and it is important to consider these risks as we develop and use AI technology. 
One potential danger is that AI could be used to harm people. For example, if an AI system is used to control a military drone or a self-driving car, it could make decisions that result in injury or death. 
Another potential danger is that AI could be used to spread misinformation or manipulate people. For example, an AI system could create fake news stories or social media posts that are designed to influence people's opinions or behavior. 
A third potential danger is that AI could lead to the loss of jobs. As AI systems become more advanced, they may be able to perform tasks that are currently done by humans. This could result in many people losing their jobs and potentially struggling to find new employment. 
A fourth potential danger is that AI could be used to violate people's privacy. For example, an AI system could be used to gather personal information about people without their knowledge or consent, and this information could be used for malicious purposes. 
Overall, it is important to carefully consider the potential risks and dangers associated with AI, and to take steps to mitigate these risks as we develop and use AI technology.

question: How come I 'm perfectly healthy even though I drink only 1 glass of water per week(ish ) , and the healthy amount is 8 - 12 glasses per day ? ? Please explain like I'm five.

It is not healthy to drink only one glass of water per week. The human body needs a certain amount of water each day to function properly. Water is essential for many bodily functions, including maintaining the proper balance of bodily fluids, regulating body temperature, and helping to digestion and metabolism. When you don't get enough water, your body can become dehydrated, which can lead to a variety of health problems. 
It is generally recommended that adults drink 8-12 cups (64-96 ounces) of water per day to stay hydrated. question: Where do old blood cells go in our body when they die ? I know where and how blood is produced , but what about the residue ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Old or damaged red blood cells are removed from circulation and replaced with new ones. When red blood cells are no longer able to function properly, they are removed from circulation by special cells called macrophages. Macrophages are found in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, and they are responsible for scavenging and removing old or damaged cells from the body. When a macrophage encounters a red blood cell that is no longer able to function properly, it engulfs the cell and breaks it down into its constituent parts. The macrophage then recycles these parts, using them to create new cells or to perform other important functions in the body. So, when an old red blood cell dies, it is removed from circulation and its parts are recycled by the body to be used again.

question: Why is it so much worse to have a body - temperature of 36 degrees celsius than to have a 40 degrees celsius fever ? Even though the difference with a normal temperature is obviously bigger with the fever . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
A normal body temperature is around 37 degrees Celsius (98.6 degrees Fahrenheit). A fever is when your body temperature is higher than normal, usually because you are fighting off an infection or illness. A temperature of 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) is considered a high fever and can be dangerous if it lasts for a long time. 
On the other hand, a body temperature of 36 degrees Celsius (96.8 degrees Fahrenheit) is lower than normal and is called hypothermia. Hypothermia can occur when your body loses heat faster than it can produce it, and it can be very dangerous because it can cause your body to stop functioning properly. For example, if your body temperature is too low, your heart and brain may not work correctly, and you may feel very tired or confused. 
So, it is important to try to maintain a normal body temperature, and if you have a fever, it is important to try to bring your body temperature down to a normal level. If your body temperature is too low, it is important to try to warm up your body and bring it back to a normal temperature.

question: What do transport companies that say " Logistics " actually do ? I see this very often on large trucks here in the U.S. and in Europe . Please explain like I'm five.

Transport companies that say "Logistics" typically handle the planning and coordination of the movement of goods and materials from one place to another. This can include everything from managing the transportation of the goods to organizing the storage and handling of the goods at different stages of their journey. 
In simpler terms, logistics companies help businesses and organizations get the things they need from one place to another, whether it's across town or across the country. They might use trucks, planes, ships, or trains to move the goods, and they might work with a variety of different partners, such as warehouses and distribution centers, to make sure everything gets to where it needs to go smoothly and efficiently. 
So, if you see a truck with the word "Logistics" written on it, it's likely that the company is responsible for helping to transport goods from one place to another as part of a larger supply chain.

question: How come the sun does n't warm up Winter air even though the rays are still warm ? Always wondered how i can stand in the sun on a cold day and it 's rays still warm me up . Possible stupid question . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The sun's rays do still warm the air on a cold day, but the heat doesn't always reach the surface of the Earth because the Earth's atmosphere acts as a barrier. Some of the heat from the sun is absorbed by the atmosphere and then radiated back into space, while some of it is absorbed by the Earth's surface and then reradiated back into the atmosphere as infrared radiation. 
During the winter, the air is colder because the Earth is tilted on its axis, which means that the sun's rays are not as direct as they are during the summer. This can cause the heat from the sun to be less effective at warming the air. 
However, even on a cold day, you can still feel the warmth of the sun's rays because the sun is still emitting heat, and this heat can reach your skin and warm you up. So even though the air may not feel very warm, the sun's rays can still make you feel warm and comfortable.

question: Why did n't dinosaurs evolve to be inteligent but we did ? What was different back then ? I mean dinosaurs were here for 60 million years and we are here just for thousands . Please explain like I'm five.

Dinosaurs and humans evolved on Earth during different time periods, with dinosaurs existing much earlier than humans. Dinosaurs first appeared on Earth around 230 million years ago, while humans evolved much more recently, around 200,000 years ago. 
During the time that dinosaurs lived on Earth, the environment was very different than it is today. The planet was much warmer, and there were no mammals or birds. The dominant land animals were reptiles, including dinosaurs. 
Over time, dinosaurs evolved to be well-suited for their environment and the challenges they faced. Some dinosaurs were herbivores, or plant-eaters, and evolved to have strong jaws and teeth for grinding up plants. Other dinosaurs were carnivores, or meat-eaters, and evolved to have sharp teeth and claws for catching and killing prey. 
However, dinosaurs did not evolve to be intelligent in the same way that humans did. Intelligence in animals is often linked to the size of their brain relative to their body size, and the brains of most dinosaurs were relatively small compared to their body size. Humans, on the other hand, evolved to have relatively large brains compared to our body size, which has helped us to develop complex societies, technologies, and cultures. 
It's important to remember that evolution is a process that takes place over millions of years, and it is influenced by a variety of factors, including the environment, the availability of resources, and the challenges that an animal must face in order to survive and reproduce. Different animals evolve different traits and abilities based on these factors, which is why some animals are more intelligent than others.

question: Difference in English and American spelling ? Why in the UK do we include the letter ' u ' in words like flavour , colour , contour etc . but in America they leave it out . Please explain like I'm five.

Daniel Webster was American and compiled the first dictionary of the language in the U.S. He felt that spelling should be simplified , so left out extra letters in color and flavor , shortened program , etc . Of course , he obviously did n't reform everything , since we still have through and rough and cough and countless other nonsensical spellings in both British and American English .

question: With Mt. Everest growing at a rate of two inches per year would the peak eventually reach space ? What are the limits on something like this ? Please explain like I'm five.

Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world, with a peak that reaches an elevation of about 29,029 feet (8,848 meters) above sea level. It is not actually growing in height, but rather, it is being uplifted by the movement of the Earth's crust. This process is called tectonic uplift, and it occurs when the Earth's plates collide and push against each other. 
As for whether the peak of Mount Everest could eventually reach space, the answer is no. The Earth's atmosphere extends about 62 miles (100 kilometers) above the surface of the Earth, and the peak of Mount Everest is much shorter than that. Even if Mount Everest were to continue to be uplifted at a rate of two inches per year, it would take many thousands of years for it to reach the edge of the atmosphere. 
There are also other factors that limit the height that a mountain can reach. For example, the weight of the mountain itself can cause it to sink down into the Earth's crust. Additionally, erosion caused by wind and water can gradually wear away at the mountain, causing it to become shorter over time. 
So, to sum it up, Mount Everest is not going to grow tall enough to reach space. It is being uplifted by the movement of the Earth's plates, but there are other factors that limit its height and prevent it from growing indefinitely.

question: Genetically , how does a red head baby come to be ? My boyfriend is a ginger and he has tried to explain this to me several times , but it goes over my head . Somebody please dumb it down for me ! Please explain like I'm five.

If a gene is dominant , even if there is a recessive gene , the dominant gene is the one that determines physical traits ( example : RR has the same physical traits as Rr ) . If a gene is recessive , you need two copies of the recessive gene , because Rr results in the dominant trait instead ( example : rr for recessive trait ) . Red hair is recessive , so it requires either two parents with red hair or two parents with genes for red hair ( example : Rr paired with Rr , which has a chance to produce rr ) . If his parents do not have red hair but he does , it means that his parents both had Rr as their genotype .

question: How do they find out the information that goes on Nutrition Facts labels ? Like number of calories , fat content , vitamin content , etc . etc . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: There 's a database of ingredients that has nutritional info for a variety of foods . When you make up a recipe you figure out the amount of nutrients and calories based on how much of each ingredient was used . For each ingredient in the database , they dried out the food and burned it and measured how much energy was produced by the burning . The tool is called a calorimeter , and it 's more or less an insulated box where you burn stuff in the bottom and have a bowl of water on top and measure how much the water temperature goes up ( 1 degree per cubic centimeter is a calorie ) . For everything else , like vitamins , etc . , they 've worked out chemical procedures for separating out the materials in the food ( generally by mashing and pouring a solvent over it and the pouring through a tube filled with special sand calleda " column " ) . They use special instruments that can identify the molecules and how much there is ( the exact technique varies depending on the material ) . The important part is that they do n't run these tests on every food , just the basic ingredients . You can work out the nutritional content based on the recipe . Mind you , some of the cooking or processing might affect the nutritional content , so , in some cases they 've tested foods cooked different ways . It 's always an educated guess because foods vary in their nutritional value based on all sorts of things ( like when it was harvested , how well it was watered , etc ) .

question: How do they find out the information that goes on Nutrition Facts labels ? Like number of calories , fat content , vitamin content , etc . etc . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Nutrition facts labels are required by law to be on most packaged foods in the United States. The information on these labels is based on scientific research and testing. 
To find out the number of calories in a food, researchers use a special machine called a bomb calorimeter. They put a small amount of the food in the machine and burn it. The heat that is given off is measured, and from this, the number of calories in the food can be calculated. 
To find out the amount of fat, protein, and other nutrients in a food, researchers use a process called proximate analysis. This involves using special chemicals to break down the food into its different parts, such as fat, protein, and carbohydrates. The amounts of these nutrients can then be measured. 
Vitamin and mineral content can also be determined through laboratory testing. Researchers can use special equipment to measure the amounts of different vitamins and minerals in a food. 
Overall, finding out the information that goes on nutrition facts labels requires careful scientific research and testing.

question: Why is it mostly men who are colorblind ? I 'm Curious . I am a male who can see minute color differences but have many friends who ca n't tell red from blue . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Color blindness needs a 2 dominate alleles to become expressed in the person normally ( this is how it works with females ) but .. It is also a sex - linked trait . Males are missing the ' slot ' for that the color blindness allele in their Y chromosome , it can only be expressed in their X chromosome . Therefore if a male receives one dominate allele from their mother / father they will be color blind . This is why males tend to be colorblind more then females , you only need one dominate color - blindness allele to be color blind whereas a female needs 2 dominant alleles for it to be expressed in females ( because they have two X chromosomes ) . Really simple explanation and there is a lot more to it but hopefully this helps .

So, to explain it like you're five: Color blindness is a special way that some people's brains see colors that is different from most people. Boys are more likely to be colorblind than girls because it is something that is passed down from their mother.

question: What mystic wood are electric poles made of , and how is that they never need to be replaced ? I 've literally never in my life seen a single one replaced . Boggles my mind . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: I worked for a utility in the department that was responsible for inspecting the wooden poles . Here 's how they test if the pole is still sturdy enough . First , they hit the pole with a hammer , listening to determine if it is hollow . Poles usually rot from the inside out . They then drill small holes in the pole near the ground . They stick a long hook inside and feel whether the wood is still hard or if it has started to rot . If so , they can also measure how much of the diameter is rotten . They then place drying agents in the holes they drilled and cap the holes with wooden plugs . The drying agents will absorb the moisture and slow down the rotting . As said before , the poles are treated with some kind of preservative before being installed . The wood is usually very dry so it has set . Hence , it wo n't warp much and wo n't be affected by rain and snow . Typically , poles will need to be replaced if they are physically broken : hit by a car , touched by a nearby fire , struck by lightning . In warmer climates , a big issue is insects . They will hollow out the pole and nest inside . Sometimes , it 's hard to actually notice because the outside wood looks fine . A pole that was properly prepared before installation and that had an easy life ( no rotting , no insects , not hit by a snow plow ) can last up to 100 years ( we 've seen a few of them during our inspections ) .

question: Why is so much of the ocean unexplored ? If humans can go into space and land on stuff , why ca n't we explore more of the ocean ? Please explain like I'm five.

question: Why did we go from a space shuttle , back to a small capsule that must land in the ocean for the Orion Mission ? Why are we using a return capsule instead when we have a spaceship ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The Space Shuttle was a reusable spacecraft that was used by NASA for a number of missions between 1981 and 2011. It was designed to be able to carry people and cargo into space, and then return to Earth and land like an airplane. However, the Space Shuttle had some limitations. It could only carry a certain amount of cargo and it could only stay in space for a limited amount of time before it needed to return to Earth. 
The Orion spacecraft is a new spacecraft that is being developed by NASA to take people further into space than ever before, including to the Moon and eventually to Mars. Unlike the Space Shuttle, the Orion spacecraft is not reusable. It is designed to be used just once for a single mission, and then discarded. 
One reason why the Orion spacecraft is designed this way is because it is going to be used for much longer missions than the Space Shuttle was. The Space Shuttle could only stay in space for a few weeks at a time, but the Orion spacecraft is being designed to stay in space for months or even years at a time. It needs to be able to carry a lot of supplies and equipment for the astronauts to use during those long missions. 
Another reason why the Orion spacecraft is designed to land in the ocean is because it is going to be traveling much faster and further than the Space Shuttle. When it re-enters the Earth's atmosphere, it will be moving at a much higher speed and will need to use a heat shield to protect itself from the heat and friction of re-entry. When the Orion spacecraft lands in the ocean, it will use parachutes to slow down and then float on the water until it can be retrieved by a special recovery team. 
I hope that helps to explain the difference between the Space Shuttle and the Orion spacecraft!

question: How do stop lights work ? I realize how stupid a question this is but other than peak times , how does it know when to change . I assume that at peak times there are programmed timers that change . Thanks . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! Stop lights are used to control the flow of traffic at intersections. When you approach a stop light, you'll see a red light, a yellow light, and a green light. The red light means that you need to stop and wait for the light to change. The yellow light means that the light is about to turn red, so you should stop if you can do so safely. The green light means that you can go through the intersection, but you should still be cautious and make sure it's safe to proceed. 
Now, how does the stop light know when to change? At non-peak times, stop lights use sensors to detect when there are cars waiting at the intersection. When a car is waiting at the intersection, the stop light will stay red for that direction until the sensor no longer detects a car. This helps to keep traffic moving smoothly and efficiently. 
At peak times, when there is more traffic, the stop light may be programmed to follow a set schedule. For example, the light may stay green for one direction for a certain amount of time, then turn red and stay red for a certain amount of time, then turn green for the other direction. This helps to keep traffic flowing and prevent backups.

question: Why does plastic turn white when bent or stretched ? Title Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When plastic is bent or stretched, it is subjected to mechanical stress. This can cause the molecules in the plastic to become rearranged, causing the plastic to appear white or cloudy. 
Plastic is made up of long chains of molecules called polymers. These molecules are held together by chemical bonds, which give the plastic its strength and rigidity. When the plastic is subjected to mechanical stress, such as when it is bent or stretched, the bonds between the molecules can become strained or broken. As a result, the molecules become rearranged and the plastic may appear white or cloudy. 
This phenomenon is known as "stress whitening," and it is a common occurrence in many types of plastic. It is usually temporary, and the plastic will return to its original color once the stress is relieved. However, if the plastic is subjected to too much stress, it can become permanently damaged, causing it to break or become deformed.

question: Number e. It is basic calculus and needed to calculate interests ... but I can not make it work on my head . Any simple concept or proof to stick to ? In basic english , I am not a math guy :( Please explain like I'm five.
answer: For compounding interest : If you have an account that starts with $ 1 and yields 100 % interest a year , you will have $ 2 at the end . 1+(1 * 1 ) = 2 If the interest compounds by half the amount in half the time ( 50 % every six months ) , you have after six months : 1+(0.5 * 1 ) = 1.5 And after a year : 1.5+(0.5 * 1.5 ) = 2.25 So your interest for the year is : 1 * 1.5 * 1.5 = 1*(1.5)^2 Because each six month period , your money is multiplied by 1.5 ( adding 50 % ) . If you do it 1/10th of the year for 10 % , the equation becomes : 1*(1.1)^10=2.59 ... Every 1/100th of the year for 1 % 1*(1.01)^100=2.705 ... The equation is generalised to for n events : 1*(1+(1 / n))^n And as n gets larger and larger the resulting number approaches e.

question: Number e. It is basic calculus and needed to calculate interests ... but I can not make it work on my head . Any simple concept or proof to stick to ? In basic english , I am not a math guy :( Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The number e is a mathematical constant that represents the base of the natural logarithm. It is approximately equal to 2.71828 and is denoted by the symbol "e". 
The number e is an important mathematical constant that arises in many different areas of mathematics and physics. It appears in various formulas involving exponential growth and decay, and it is also closely related to the concept of compound interest in finance. 
To understand the concept of e, it can be helpful to think about the concept of compound interest. When you receive interest on a savings account or investment, that interest is usually calculated based on the amount of money you have invested. For example, if you have $100 invested at an annual interest rate of 10%, then you will receive $10 in interest after one year. 
However, if you receive that interest and then reinvest it, you will earn even more interest on your original investment. This is because you are earning interest on the original investment as well as on the interest you received. This is known as compound interest. 
The number e is related to compound interest because it represents the rate at which an investment would grow if the interest were compounded continuously, rather than just once per year. This means that the interest is being reinvested and earning more interest constantly, rather than just once per year. 
The formula for calculating compound interest using e is: 
A = P * e^(rt) 
Where: 
A is the amount of money you will have after a certain number of years.
P is the amount of money you are investing.
r is the annual interest rate.
t is the number of years you are investing the money. 
So, for example, if you invested $100 at an annual interest rate of 10% for one year, using the formula above, you would calculate the final amount of money you would have like this: 
A = 100 * e^(0.1*1)
= 100 * 2.71828
= $271.83 
I hope this helps to give you a basic understanding of the number e and how it is related to compound interest. Let me know if you have any other questions!

question: Is it better for me to sleep 10 pm - 6 am ( 8hr ) or 12 am - 8 am ( 8hr ) ? And which one give me more energy ? Please explain like I'm five.

It's generally best for adults to get 7-9 hours of sleep per night. The specific timing of when you go to sleep and wake up is less important, as long as you're getting enough sleep overall. If you have trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, there are a few things you can try to improve your sleep quality:

question: How do motherboards and circuit boards get completely ruined by electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) ? Seems like such a small amount of electricity compared to what is drawn from the Power supply Please explain like I'm five.
answer: I 'm a semiconductor reliability engineer , and I used to do a lot of ESD failure analysis : Integrated circuits have very , very tiny features . Electrostatic discharges do n't have a lot of total charge , but the rate of charge flow ( current ) can exceed several amps for a short period of time . Since the features that the current flows through are quite small , the current densities reach incredible levels .... enough to melt metal conductors and even the [ silicon itself ] ( URL_0 ) . That 's pretty awesome , when you keep in mind that it take in excess of 1400 degrees C to melt Si . Similarly , the voltages can be quite high ( thousands of volts ) , sometimes causing rupture of the very thin insulators in an integrated circuit . ( But the killer is more often the heating . ) ESD almost never directly damages a circuit board . But it can short a component on the board , making bad things happen to the board as a secondary effect .

question: How do motherboards and circuit boards get completely ruined by electrostatic discharge ( ESD ) ? Seems like such a small amount of electricity compared to what is drawn from the Power supply Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Electrostatic discharge (ESD) is a sudden flow of electricity between two charged objects. It can happen when two objects with different electrical charges come into contact with each other, or when an object becomes charged by friction or contact with another charged object. 
Motherboards and circuit boards contain many small electronic components, such as transistors and capacitors, which are very sensitive to ESD. When an ESD event occurs, the sudden flow of electricity can damage or destroy these components, rendering the motherboard or circuit board inoperable. 
Think of it like this: Imagine you have a bucket of water and you want to pour it into a glass. If you pour the water slowly, it will fill up the glass without any problems. But if you pour the water too quickly, it might overflow and spill out, causing a mess. It's similar with ESD and electronic components. A small amount of electricity flowing through the component slowly might not cause any damage, but a large, sudden flow of electricity can be too much for the component to handle and it can be damaged or destroyed. 
So even though the amount of electricity involved in an ESD event might seem small compared to the power drawn from a power supply, it can still be enough to cause serious damage to sensitive electronic components. That's why it's important to take precautions to prevent ESD when working with electronic equipment.

question: Why 2 liters of 100 % pure orange juice cost ~4 $ while it takes way more than 4 $ worth of real oranges to get the same amount of juice ? Even by using Professional juice extractor at home . Where 's the catch ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: This is a bit of a long story so bear with me . So I worked for a while in produce in a large supermarket as a young inquisitive school kid . The produce manager was a wise old man who had dealt with that job longer than I 've been alive . To pass the time i would ask him about lots of things we came across . Partially to test him and see if he knew , mostly because he almost always knew and the answers were interesting . We did a big citrus sale every year . After loading , stacking , checking dates and sources , rotating , and shelving near a ton of assorted oranges and other similar citrus , I noticed one thing . None of it was from Florida ! Thinking I finally had a question to stump the boss man , I asked him . " Why do n't we sell any oranges from Florida ? " " We do . " " No way . Every box I checked today was from someplace other than Florida . " " You did n't check the right boxes . " " Show me where the Florida oranges are then old man . " He took me to the orange juice . Nearly every single orange juice across the board was Florida orange juice . Frustrated i even checked the frozen section of the store . Every last one there . " Why is it only florida oranges that make juice ? Surely Florida oranges are good enough to sell too . I 've eaten oranges fresh off the tree from there . " " You 're right . You can only eat them there tho . " Perplexed ? I was too . " You remember having to check the sources of all the oranges right ? " " Yea . I had to make the tags for the shelves for it too . " " You 're not allowed to sell fresh Florida oranges outside of Florida . They carry plant infections that right now are only found in Florida . To prevent them from spreading , they have to either be processed into juice or sold within the state . " Since Florida produces a large market share of oranges , and nearly all of the orange juice , prices are very low in comparison to oranges from other places . They are shoehorned into a tiny market with extreme supply . The only way to get rid of all their juice is to sell it cheap . It just so happens to be a bit cheaper than fresh oranges . At least in the US . Since you used liters as a unit of measurement you might be from someplace which does n't produce locally . In that case , the added cost of fresh oranges is from logistics . It is more costly to move fresh fruit than it is to move comparable amounts of " liquid fruit . " Transportation is made even cheaper by concentrating it initially , then adding water later .

question: Why 2 liters of 100 % pure orange juice cost ~4 $ while it takes way more than 4 $ worth of real oranges to get the same amount of juice ? Even by using Professional juice extractor at home . Where 's the catch ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are several reasons why the cost of 100% pure orange juice might be higher than the cost of the oranges used to make it. 
First, it takes a lot of oranges to make just a liter of orange juice. The average orange yields about 3-4 ounces of juice, so it would take about 8-10 oranges to make a liter of orange juice. This means that even if the cost of oranges is relatively low, the cost of the juice can still be relatively high because of the large quantity of oranges needed. 
Second, producing and packaging orange juice is a complex process that involves many steps and costs. The oranges must be harvested, transported to a processing facility, cleaned, juiced, pasteurized, and bottled or packaged. Each of these steps requires labor and resources, which add to the overall cost of the juice. 
Finally, the cost of orange juice may also be affected by factors such as demand, supply, and transportation costs. If there is a high demand for orange juice and a limited supply of oranges, the price of orange juice may be higher. Similarly, if the cost of transporting the oranges or the finished juice is high, this can also contribute to the overall cost of the juice.

question: Why does every animal have two ( 2 ) eyes ? I know spiders have 8 . But with such diversity in the world , should n't a few species have 4 , 6 , or even just one ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: There are five reasons why animals have two eyes ( rather than one ): 1 . Better depth perception . The image on the two eyes is slightly different and by comparing the locations of the images , an animal can locate objects in depth . It is not the only depth cue but it is an important one for predator or tree dwelling species . 2 . Wider field of view . The animal can see more of the visual world with two eyes than with one . 3 . Each eye has a blind spot , and each eye covers the blind spot of the other . There is a blindspot in each eye where the optic nerve leaves the eye , and in that region of the eye , there are no photoreceptors so you are blind there . However , the other eye covers that region so you still know what is there . 4 . Easier to see dim lights with two eyes than one . Two eyes both catching light particles will have a lower threshold for detecting dim lights than just one eye . 5 . Most importantly : as a spare ! An animal still has a good chance of surviving with one eye , but very little chance of reproducing with none . Now , why do n't we have MORE than two eyes ? Likely because , in mammals , the number of new nerve cells that would have to be supported by an additional eye would not be worth the benefits of having it . Nerve cells are the hungriest cells in the body , and more of the cerebral cortex is devoted to vision than any other function . Having additional eyes ( beyond two ) in mammals would require huge numbers of new nerve cells to support them , and the metabolic cost would not be worth the benefit .

question: Why does every animal have two ( 2 ) eyes ? I know spiders have 8 . But with such diversity in the world , should n't a few species have 4 , 6 , or even just one ? Please explain like I'm five.

Overall, the number of eyes that an animal has is a result of evolution. Over time, certain traits that helped animals survive and reproduce became more common in a population, while other traits became less common. This process is called natural selection. In the case of eyes, having two eyes has proven to be a useful trait for many animals, so it has become more common in a variety of species. However, there are still some animals that have a different number of eyes, and this can be due to the specific evolutionary pressures that they have faced.

question: How are sattelites and drones in space capable of sending pictures / audio back to earth from such great distances ? How can Curiosity send pictures on Mars back to Earth ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Satellites and drones in space are able to send pictures and audio back to Earth using radio waves. Radio waves are a type of electromagnetic radiation, just like light, heat, and X-rays. They are invisible to us, but they can be used to transmit information, such as pictures and audio, over long distances. 
To send pictures or audio from a satellite or drone in space back to Earth, the device first takes a picture or records some audio. Then, it converts the picture or audio into a special code called a "signal" using a device called a "transmitter." The signal is then sent to a special antenna on the satellite or drone, which sends the signal out into space using radio waves. 
The signal travels through space and is received by a special antenna on Earth, called a "receiver." The receiver decodes the signal and converts it back into a picture or audio that we can see or hear. 
The same process is used to send pictures and audio from the Curiosity rover on Mars back to Earth. Curiosity is a robot that was sent to explore Mars and take pictures and other measurements of the planet. It sends the pictures and other data back to Earth using a special antenna and transmitter, just like a satellite or drone.

Three-parent babies are a type of assisted reproductive technology that allows three people to contribute genetic material to the creation of a child. This type of technology is used when a couple is unable to have a baby using traditional methods, such as in vitro fertilization (IVF), due to certain medical conditions or genetic issues. 
Here's how it works: 
1. One woman provides an egg, which contains her genetic material. 
2. A second woman provides a fertilized egg, which contains genetic material from her and a man (usually her partner). This egg is also called a "donor egg." 
3. The fertilized egg from the second woman is then inserted into the uterus of the first woman, who will carry and give birth to the baby. 
4. The baby will have genetic material from three people: the first woman, the second woman, and the man whose sperm was used to fertilize the second woman's egg. 
This type of assisted reproduction is controversial and is not allowed in all countries. It is only used in cases where the couple is unable to have a baby using traditional methods and where there is a medical need for the child to have the genetic material of three people.

question: How to people die in " stampedes " ( Like Black Friday or the New Year 's stampede of people in Shanghai ) ? What is the cause of death and how does it actually happen ? Please explain like I'm five.

Crushing happens when someone is stuck up against an immovable object and the crowd surge from behind presses them so hard that they are crushed / suffocated . Trampling occurs when someone falls , no one sees / hears , and they are simply stepped on until they are injured enough to be killed . Sometimes , due to the pressure of the crowd , even if people are trying to pull the person up , they are forced over them lest they fall and be trampled as well . In both scenarios , the problem is the back pressure from the people near the rear who ca n't see the dangerous conditions that are occurring at the front of the stampede . This is a particular problem when there is a dangerous situation to the rear ( such as in a fire , trying to escape through narrow doors ) as everyone wants to haul ass out of there , but there is an obstruction up front .

question: How do surveys account for the inherit bias and lying in the answers it receives ? I always feel like I am bias in certain questions and wonder how it affects my outcome . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Surveys are inevitably biased to some degree , but bias can be minimised using a number of strategies : Survey design - trying to get the wording and ordering of questions in such a way that respondents are not influenced to answer in certain ways . Size of sample - a large sample with more respondents could potentially minimise bias , because even if a couple of participants deliberately lie , their impact on the overall findings is minimal . Control groups - testing the same survey with different target groups or slightly different formats ( for example changes to the order and wording of questions ) to see what difference this makes . Careful reporting - the reporting of survey results need to explicitly acknowledge potential biases , the gaps in the sample and the limits of the methodology . The findings must not be treated as ' facts ' but as evidence that is limited by the nature of the research . For example , rather than report that " our survey found that 15 % of people cheat on their wives " , a good researcher will report that " 15 % of survey respondents - mostly white males in their 40s - reported cheating on their wives " .

question: How do surveys account for the inherit bias and lying in the answers it receives ? I always feel like I am bias in certain questions and wonder how it affects my outcome . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Surveys try to account for bias and lying in a few different ways. Here are a few examples: 
1. Random sampling: Survey researchers try to select a representative sample of people to participate in the survey. By randomly selecting participants, researchers aim to minimize the chance that certain groups are overrepresented or underrepresented in the sample. 
2. Anonymity: Surveys may be designed to be anonymous, which means that the researchers do not know who filled out the survey. This can help reduce bias because people may feel more comfortable being honest when they don't have to worry about being identified. 
3. Neutral wording: Survey questions should be worded in a neutral way, without implying a certain answer. For example, a question that asks "Do you think it is wrong to drink and drive?" might bias people towards saying "yes" because of the use of the word "wrong." Instead, a better question might be "Do you think it is safe to drink and drive?" 
4. Pilot testing: Before a survey is given to a large group of people, it is often tested with a smaller group to see if there are any problems with the questions or how they are worded. This can help researchers identify and fix any potential biases in the survey. 
I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

question: How do they shoot space movies to look like zero gravity ? I 'm talking older movies , too , like 2001 a Space Odyssey when superior editing technology was still a ways off . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are several techniques that filmmakers use to create the illusion of zero gravity in movies. One technique is called "forced perspective." This involves shooting a scene with the camera at an angle that makes objects in the foreground look larger than they are, while objects in the background appear smaller. This creates the illusion that the objects in the foreground are closer to the camera and are therefore subject to less gravity. 
Another technique is called "high-speed photography." This involves shooting a scene at a very high frame rate, typically hundreds or thousands of frames per second. When the footage is played back at a normal frame rate, it appears as though the objects in the scene are moving much more slowly than they actually are. This can be used to make it look like objects are floating or moving slowly in a weightless environment. 
In some cases, filmmakers will also use special effects and computer-generated imagery (CGI) to create the illusion of zero gravity. This can involve digitally altering the movement of objects in a scene or creating entirely digital environments that look like they are in space. 
In the past, filmmakers have also used practical effects to create the illusion of zero gravity. For example, in the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey," the filmmakers used a special rig called a "zero gravity plane" to simulate weightlessness. The plane would fly in a parabolic pattern, allowing the actors to experience brief periods of weightlessness. The filmmakers then shot the scenes during these periods and used editing techniques to make it look like the actors were in a weightless environment.

question: Why different animals have different lifespans ? I just looked up the average lifespan of a spider ( 1.5 to 2 years ) and I also heard that sharks live for centuries . I was just curious as to why there is such a huge gap . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: There 's a concept called the " Hayflick limit " , which basically says , a cell can only divide so many times before it loses the ability to . They believe it occurs on the DNA level , a piece is lost each replication , and when enough has been lost , the cell ca n't reproduce again . All living creatures are constantly breaking down , and repairing themselves with new cells . When they ca n't fix the broken parts , they begin to fail , and death is on the way . The rate the break down / repair happens , and the amount of times a cell can be replaced , varies by animal , resulting in drastically different lifespans . It 's worth mentioning , that in nature , animals ( including humans ) rarely live to this point . Predators , accidents , sickness , and excessive wear and tear ( teeth worn to the point they ca n't eat , for instance ) are generally what causes death . Dying of " old age " requires a very safe environment .

question: what 's the difference between an amp , volt , and watt ? I was just thinking about it , and despite knowing very vaguely what they are I 've no idea what they are , or the difference . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
An amp (ampere) is a unit of electrical current. It measures the flow of electrons in a circuit. 
A volt (voltage) is a unit of electrical potential difference. It measures the pressure that drives electrons through a circuit. 
A watt is a unit of power. It measures the rate at which energy is transferred or used. 
Here's an example to help you understand the difference between these three units: 
Imagine a water pipe with water flowing through it. The amps would be like the amount of water flowing through the pipe. The volts would be like the pressure of the water. And the watts would be like the rate at which the water is flowing and doing work (such as turning a turbine to generate electricity). 
So, in short: 
Amps measure the flow of electrons (current).
Volts measure the pressure that drives the electrons through the circuit (voltage).
Watts measure the rate at which energy is being transferred or used (power).

question: how come when i m having trouble sneezing looking into a bright light sets off the sneeze ? i assume this works for most people too Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sneezing is a reflex that helps to protect your body by clearing your nose of irritants, such as dust, pollen, or other substances that can cause an allergic reaction. When your nose is exposed to an irritant, it sends a signal to your brain, which then triggers the muscles in your nose, throat, and chest to contract, causing you to sneeze. 
Looking at a bright light can sometimes trigger the reflex to sneeze because the light can stimulate certain nerve fibers in your eye that are connected to the muscles in your nose and throat. These nerve fibers are called the trigeminal nerve, and they help to control the reflexes that cause you to sneeze, as well as other reflexes, such as blinking and coughing. 
So, when you look at a bright light, it can stimulate these nerve fibers, causing the muscles in your nose and throat to contract and resulting in a sneeze. This is why looking at a bright light can sometimes help to set off a sneeze when you're having trouble sneezing.

question: Why is it that in a dark or nearly dark room people can see objects better when they do n't look directly them ? Is it just how our eyes adjust to the darkness or something to do with the cones and rods ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: its do with both . when its dark , your pupils dilate letting more light in . however that does nt explain why you see better when you do nt look directly at an object . it turns out when you re looking directly at something , the light is nt going all around the inside of your eye , its focused on a very small point a mm or two large . its called the fovea , the yellow spot or the macula lutea ( put simply ) . this spot is where almost all of your cones ( colored vision ) cells are . most of the rest of the eye is made of rods . now colored vision is nt particularly useful in the dark , so when we want to see in the dark , we want to focus light on the rods . we do this by looking slightly to the sides so the light hits the rods instead of the fovea .

question: Why is it that in a dark or nearly dark room people can see objects better when they do n't look directly them ? Is it just how our eyes adjust to the darkness or something to do with the cones and rods ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
In a dark or nearly dark room, it can be easier to see objects if you don't look directly at them because of a phenomenon called "dark adaptation." When you go from a well-lit environment to a dark one, your eyes take some time to adjust. During this process, your eyes become more sensitive to low levels of light, which makes it easier to see in the dark. 
Your eyes have two types of cells called rods and cones that help you see. Rods are more sensitive to low levels of light and are responsible for your night vision. Cones are more sensitive to bright light and are responsible for your color vision. When you're in a dark room, your rods are more active and your cones are less active, which is why it can be harder to see colors in the dark. 
So when you're in a dark room, it can be easier to see objects if you don't look directly at them because your rods are more sensitive to low levels of light, and looking directly at something can cause your cones to become more active, which can make it harder to see.
