question: the Bahá'í Faith An old friend of mine recently posted on Facebook that she went to a Bahá'í school for a retreat . After googling , I realize this is a religion . But the wikipedia page is ... dense . Care to pare it down ? Please explain like I'm five.

Sayyid Ali - Muhammad claimed that he knew the Mahdi was coming , and that he would be able to identify the Mahdi . Mírzá Husayn ` Alí Núrí was the one who the Bab " prophesied , " he claimed to be the Mahdi . His teachings were written by his son , and Ali Nuri was proclaimed to be , all at once , the Mahdi ( messianic figure of Islam ) , the Matreiya ( messianic figure of Mahayana Buddhism ) , and the Messiah ( or Second coming of Christ ) . question: Winter and summer Can someone explain why when sun is closest to sun in orbit its winter on earth . When earth is away from sun its summer . Should nt electro - magnetic waves lose some of its energy as they travel ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Winter and Summer are n't caused by the earth moving towards and away from the sun . Earth 's orbit is elliptical , like all orbits , but it is n't eccentric enough to cause that kind of variation . The season 's are caused by Earth 's axial tilt , which is around 23 degrees . When the northern hemisphere is tilted towards the sun between June and September , it is exposed to more direct solar radiation and temperatures rise . From December to March , the northern hemisphere tilts away from the sun and temperatures fall . Since the southern hemisphere is on the opposite side of the earth , it experiences summer when the north experiences winter and vice - versa .

question: Winter and summer Can someone explain why when sun is closest to sun in orbit its winter on earth . When earth is away from sun its summer . Should nt electro - magnetic waves lose some of its energy as they travel ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! The Earth's orbit around the sun is not a perfect circle, but rather an ellipse, or a slightly oval-shaped circle. This means that the Earth is slightly closer to the sun at certain times of the year and slightly farther away at other times. When the Earth is closest to the sun, it is winter in the Northern Hemisphere (where it is currently winter) and summer in the Southern Hemisphere. When the Earth is farther away from the sun, it is summer in the Northern Hemisphere and winter in the Southern Hemisphere. 
The reason for this has to do with the tilt of the Earth's axis. The Earth's axis is an imaginary line that goes through the North and South Poles and around which the Earth rotates. The Earth's axis is tilted about 23.5 degrees relative to the plane of its orbit around the sun. This means that different parts of the Earth receive different amounts of sunlight throughout the year. 
During the winter in the Northern Hemisphere, the North Pole is tilted away from the sun, so the Northern Hemisphere receives less direct sunlight. This is why it is colder in the winter. During the summer in the Northern Hemisphere, the North Pole is tilted towards the sun, so the Northern Hemisphere receives more direct sunlight. This is why it is warmer in the summer. 
As for the question about electromagnetic waves losing energy as they travel, electromagnetic waves do not lose energy as they travel through empty space. However, they can be absorbed or scattered by objects that they encounter, which can affect their intensity (how bright or strong they are). This is why the sun appears to be less bright in the winter than in the summer, even though it is actually the same distance away from the Earth.

question: Why do alcoholic drinks dehydrate you ? Why you get such bad hangovers due to dehydration from , beer , for example ? Surely the beer has water in it that contributes , like just plain water , to your bodies hydration levels ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: First , the body pays special attention to alcohol . It 's a small molecule and gets very quickly through the walls of the gut into the bloodstream and then to the brain . Second , if you weigh 60 kilograms , you generate about 60 milliliters of urine each hour . And for 80 kilograms , about 80 milliliters per hour , and so on . Third , we humans seem to prefer to drink our alcohol in 10 gram lumps . Ten grams of alcohol is about 12.5 milliliters ( but you can call it 10 mL and still be fairly accurate ) . So each glass of beer , wine , or spirits has about 10 grams of alcohol . Fourth , alcohol interferes with the mechanism that regulates the water levels in our body . So now , a little anatomy and physiology . In your brain is a small gland called the pituitary gland . It is divided into two sections : the front ; and the back . The back section is called the posterior pituitary . One of the hormones made by the posterior pituitary gland is called vasopressin , or anti - diuretic hormone ( ADH ) . Diuresis is a fancy word meaning urination . Now suppose that you are really dehydrated . So the volume of water in your body is low . But you still have just as many salts floating in this reduced volume of water . So these salts are now more concentrated in the reduced volume of water that you have when you are dehydrated . Your body has detectors that can sense both the saltiness of your water , and the volume of the water . If these detectors reckon that you are dehydrated , they send a signal to the posterior pituitary gland , which starts pumping out ADH . The job of ADH is to stop you urinating , so you hang on to your precious water . You reduce your normal rate of making urine . Alcohol does the opposite . It reduces how much ADH you make , so it increases how much urine you produce . Each shot of alcohol that you drink forces your kidneys to generate an extra 120 milliliters of urine on top of the normal 60–80 milliliters per hour .

question: Why do alcoholic drinks dehydrate you ? Why you get such bad hangovers due to dehydration from , beer , for example ? Surely the beer has water in it that contributes , like just plain water , to your bodies hydration levels ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Alcoholic drinks can dehydrate you because they can increase the amount of urine your body produces. When you drink alcohol, your body is more likely to need to urinate, which can lead to a loss of fluids. Additionally, alcohol can interfere with the hormone that helps to regulate your body's hydration levels, which can contribute to dehydration. 
While it is true that beer does contain some water, it is also high in alcohol, which can contribute to dehydration. This is why it is important to drink plenty of water along with alcohol to help stay hydrated. 
Hangovers can be caused by a number of factors, including dehydration, but they can also be caused by other factors such as inflammation, changes in brain chemistry, and the presence of toxins in the body. Dehydration can contribute to a hangover because it can cause symptoms like thirst, fatigue, and headache. 
To help prevent hangovers and the dehydration that can come with them, it is a good idea to drink plenty of water while you are drinking alcohol, and to continue to drink water after you are finished drinking. It is also a good idea to pace yourself when you are drinking and to try to avoid drinking too much in a short period of time.

question: Why is n't there any smoke if a candle just burns , but is there a lot of smoke if you blow it ? And where does all that smoke come from ? Edit : speelign Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When a candle burns, it produces a small amount of smoke. This smoke is made up of tiny particles of unburned wax and other substances that are released into the air as the candle burns. 
However, when you blow out a candle, you are extinguishing the flame by cutting off the oxygen supply. This can cause the candle to smoke more heavily because the wax is still hot and the flame is still burning, but it is not getting enough oxygen to continue burning cleanly. The smoke you see when you blow out a candle is made up of these unburned particles of wax and other substances that are released into the air. 
Overall, the amount of smoke that a candle produces depends on how efficiently the candle is burning. A candle that is burning cleanly and efficiently will produce less smoke than a candle that is not burning as well.

question: Could allergies eventually by phased out by evolution / natural selection ? Or do genetics play no part ? A question that was keeping me up pondering at 2 am last night . Please explain like I'm five.

Allergies are a side - effect of having the ( super complex but highly effective ) immune system that we do - this means that they are unlikely to go anywhere soon , because it would involve a fundamental change in the mechanisms of how we deal with pathogens .

question: Could allergies eventually by phased out by evolution / natural selection ? Or do genetics play no part ? A question that was keeping me up pondering at 2 am last night . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
It is possible that allergies could eventually be phased out by evolution through natural selection, but it is not a straightforward process. 
Allergies are a type of immune system response to certain substances that are normally harmless to most people. The substances that can trigger an allergic reaction are called allergens. In some people, the immune system mistakes these allergens as harmful and mounts an excessive response to them. This can cause symptoms like sneezing, itchy eyes, and difficulty breathing. 
Genetics play a role in whether or not a person develops allergies. If a person has a family history of allergies, they are more likely to develop allergies themselves. However, genetics are not the only factor. Environmental factors, such as exposure to allergens and other substances, can also affect the development of allergies. 
Natural selection is the process by which certain traits become more or less common in a population over time. The traits that are most beneficial to survival and reproduction are more likely to be passed on to future generations. If a trait is harmful or disadvantageous, it is less likely to be passed on. 
In theory, if a trait like allergies was consistently harmful and caused people to have a lower chance of surviving and reproducing, it could eventually be phased out through natural selection. However, this process can take a long time and is not guaranteed. 
There is also the possibility that allergies could be beneficial to some people in certain situations. For example, allergies to certain substances could help protect against certain diseases or parasites. In these cases, the trait might not be selected against, and could even be passed on to future generations. 
So, to answer your question, it is possible that allergies could eventually be phased out through natural selection, but it is not a simple process and is influenced by many factors.

question: Why ca n't I start my own nation ? What is stopping me from finding a island and starting the country of Doge ? How does a nation become recognized as a country ? Please explain like I'm five.

question: How can someone tell that I googled their name ? A few minutes after googling a friend 's name , I received a text from him telling me that he saw that . Is it because he 's in my contact list ? Please explain like I'm five.

question: The latest Supreme Court case against the ACA , or Obamacare I read through [ this article ] ( URL_0 ) but I 'm still sort of lost as to what is being challenged here . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, is a law that was passed in 2010 that made significant changes to the U.S. healthcare system. One of the main goals of the ACA was to make health insurance more accessible and affordable for people who didn't have it. The ACA did this by requiring most Americans to have health insurance, providing subsidies to help people pay for insurance, and requiring insurance companies to offer coverage to people with pre-existing health conditions. 
Recently, a group of states challenged the ACA in a case that went all the way to the Supreme Court. The states argued that the ACA was unconstitutional because Congress had passed a law in 2017 that eliminated a tax that was used to help fund the ACA. Without this tax, the states argued, the ACA was no longer constitutional. 
The Supreme Court heard arguments in the case in November 2021, and a decision is expected sometime in 2022. If the Court decides that the ACA is unconstitutional, it could have significant consequences for the millions of people who have gained health insurance through the ACA and for the U.S. healthcare system as a whole.

question: Why do we use degrees to measure both temperature and angles ? They do n't seem to share similar qualities . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Degrees are a way to measure how much something has changed or how far something has turned. 
We use degrees to measure temperature because it allows us to say how hot or cold something is compared to a standard temperature. For example, if the temperature outside is 70 degrees, that means it is warmer than 50 degrees but cooler than 90 degrees. 
We use degrees to measure angles because it allows us to say how much something has turned compared to a straight line. For example, if you turn a pencil so that it is pointing straight up, that is 0 degrees. If you turn the pencil to the right until it is pointing straight out to the side, that is 90 degrees. If you turn it all the way around in a circle, that is 360 degrees. 
Degrees are a convenient way to measure both temperature and angles because they allow us to describe how much something has changed or turned using a standard unit.

question: Why do I look so ugly when I take a picture of myself , but look good on the mirror ? Also some friends look weird in photos but look much better in person , and others just look like the same . Why ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: [ This gif will help . ] ( URL_0 ) Lighting . Lighting can change how a person looks . In normal day - to - day life , light sources , whether they be from the Sun or lightbulbs , are usually above you . When the light is here , the shadows appear in locations the brain is used to . Everything looks normal . But in a camera picture , the light is coming from the camera . This sideways approach actually ends up removing most shadows from the face , especially if the subject is directly facing the camera . The loss of shadows means a loss of details , which makes an uglier picture . This is why many selfies are taken from a downwards angle with the person 's head looking away , because it makes the flash come from a more natural angle . Take a look at how people always point a flashlight up at themselves from below when telling a spooky scary campfire story . It lights up the lower eyelid and eyebrow , leaving the actual eye socket dark . This makes a face look more like a skull , and subtly adds to the spookiness . There could be many more reasons as to why a picture looks ugly . Yellow lights / white lights . 2d image / 3d animated person .

question: Why do I look so ugly when I take a picture of myself , but look good on the mirror ? Also some friends look weird in photos but look much better in person , and others just look like the same . Why ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are a few reasons why you might look different in a photo than you do in the mirror. One reason is that cameras and mirrors show us slightly different perspectives of our faces. When you look in a mirror, you see a reflection of yourself that is facing you, so you see both sides of your face at once. In a photo, the camera is usually further away from your face, so it captures a wider view of your face, including your profile. This can sometimes make your nose or other features look bigger or more prominent in a photo than they do in the mirror. 
Another reason you might look different in a photo is because of the lighting. If the lighting in the room is different from the lighting in the photo, it can change the way your face looks. For example, if you take a photo in bright sunlight, it can create shadows on your face that aren't there when you look in the mirror. Similarly, if you take a photo with a flash, it can wash out your skin tone and make you look pale or shiny. 
Finally, it's also possible that you just see yourself differently in the mirror than you do in photos. Sometimes our brains can play tricks on us and we don't see ourselves as accurately as other people do. So even if you look the same in a photo as you do in the mirror, you might still feel like you look different. 
As for why some people look different in photos than they do in person, it could be because of any of the reasons I mentioned above, or it could be because of other factors, like the angle of the camera or the expression on their face. It's also possible that you just perceive them differently in person than you do in photos.

question: How does turning on my WiFi enable better location accuracy ? Android apps like swarm , maps usually ask me to turn on WiFi , how does it locate my phone with a greater accuracy than cellular ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! When you turn on your WiFi, your phone is able to connect to nearby WiFi networks. These networks can be used to help determine your location. 
Your phone uses something called "triangulation" to figure out where you are. Triangulation is a way to find out where you are by measuring the distance between you and a few other things. In this case, the "other things" are WiFi networks. 
When your phone connects to a WiFi network, it can figure out how far away it is from that network. It does this by measuring how strong the signal is. The stronger the signal, the closer the WiFi network is. The weaker the signal, the farther away the WiFi network is. 
Your phone can connect to multiple WiFi networks at the same time. By measuring the strength of the signals from all of these networks, it can triangulate its position and figure out exactly where it is. This is much more accurate than just using the cellular network, which can only give a rough estimate of your location. 
So, when an app asks you to turn on your WiFi, it's because it needs to use these nearby WiFi networks to help determine your location more accurately.

question: Why does store bought orange juice ( e.g. Tropicana or the like ) look and taste so different than freshly squeezed orange juice , even though on the box it says made from freshly squeezed oranges ? Thanks in advance ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Store-bought orange juice is made from freshly squeezed oranges, but the process of making it and packaging it for sale changes the way it looks and tastes. 
First, the oranges are squeezed to extract the juice. Then, the juice is pasteurized, which means it is heated to a high temperature to kill any bacteria or germs that might be in it. This helps to make the juice last longer and reduces the risk of food poisoning. 
After pasteurization, the orange juice is often stored in large tanks for a period of time before it is bottled or packaged for sale. This storage process can change the taste of the orange juice, as the flavors may become less vibrant and the juice may become less fresh-tasting. 
Additionally, some store-bought orange juice is made from a blend of juices from different types of oranges, which can also change the taste. Some brands also add extra ingredients, like sweeteners or flavorings, which can alter the taste and appearance of the orange juice. 
Overall, the process of making and packaging store-bought orange juice can cause it to taste and look different than freshly squeezed orange juice.

question: Surely music is mixed in the studio , so why does it sound better when I use a preset EQ ? Should n't it sound better with just a flat EQ on my device ? Have n't they mixed it to perfection at the studio ? ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Music is mixed in a studio to sound the best it can on a wide range of playback systems. However, different playback systems can have different characteristics that affect the way the music sounds. For example, some speakers or headphones may have a bass-heavy or treble-heavy sound, which can make the music sound unbalanced. 
Using a preset EQ on your device can help to adjust the balance of the frequencies in the music to better suit the characteristics of your particular playback system. This can make the music sound more balanced and enjoyable to listen to. 
It's also important to note that everyone has their own personal preferences when it comes to how they like their music to sound. Some people may prefer a bass-heavy sound, while others may prefer a more balanced or treble-heavy sound. Using a preset EQ can allow you to tailor the sound of the music to your personal preferences. 
So, while the music may have been mixed to sound the best it can in a studio, using a preset EQ can help to further adjust the balance of the frequencies to better suit your particular playback system and personal preferences.

question: The end of the world according to the book of revelations Not trying to start a theological debate , it 's just I want to understand the events stated on the book ( I always get lost in the allegories ) Please explain like I'm five.

question: if black friday is all positive revenue why do n't they do deals and stuff more often than once a year ? If ' being in the black ' is profit for companies , why do they limit their deals to one day of the year ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Deals and discounts are usually done for two reasons . 1 . To get rid of any long standing inventory to free - up room for new orders 2 . In anticipation of high volumes of demand ( surge in amount of customers ) When demand is expected to be extremely high , companies can afford to mark down items and offer sales , the minimal loss in revenue from marking down products is in theory supposed to be easily made up by the added amount of revenue the company will receive from the increase in demand . Companies are n't usually only striving for one of the above reasons , Black Friday is inherently a combination of both . Stores experience large surges in the amount of shoppers , so they start off by marking down the prices on inventory which they are trying to get rid of first . Usually the items marked down in price the most are items which have been on the shelves for quite sometimes , or are items which are being replaced by newer models ( or seasonal ) . Deals similar to Black Friday are n't done other times during the year , due to the cyclical nature of retail shopping . It is much more difficult to sell products like televisions or other electronics during the year as compared with the holiday season . Some companies in fact lose a good amount of money maintaining their inventory during the year , only to regain all the lost revenue during the holiday season due to the increase in consumer demand . TL : DR Giving discounts is not cost effective unless there is an increase in overall consumer demand for the products you are selling during that time period .

question: if black friday is all positive revenue why do n't they do deals and stuff more often than once a year ? If ' being in the black ' is profit for companies , why do they limit their deals to one day of the year ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Black Friday is a day when many retailers offer special sales and discounts to help kick off the holiday shopping season. It's called Black Friday because it's typically the day when retailers start to "turn a profit," or go "into the black," after being "in the red" (meaning they've been losing money) for most of the year. 
While it's true that Black Friday can be a very profitable day for retailers, there are a few reasons why they might not offer special deals and discounts more often than once a year: 
1. Limited supply: Many retailers have a limited supply of the items they are discounting on Black Friday. If they offered the same discounts more frequently, they might run out of stock or be unable to make a profit on the sale. 
2. Price sensitivity: People are more likely to buy something when it's on sale, so by offering discounts only once a year, retailers can create a sense of urgency and encourage people to shop on Black Friday. 
3. Competition: Black Friday has become a very competitive event, with retailers trying to outdo each other with bigger and better sales. If retailers offered discounts more frequently, it might not be as special or exciting for shoppers. 
4. Planning: Retailers plan their Black Friday sales well in advance and may have already purchased the items they will be discounting. If they offered discounts more frequently, they might not have enough time to plan and prepare. 
Overall, Black Friday is a way for retailers to drive traffic to their stores and websites, and generate a lot of revenue in a short period of time. However, it's just one part of their overall business strategy and they have to consider a variety of factors when deciding how and when to offer special deals and discounts.

question: - Why is the human period cycle 28 days ? I 've heard it has something to do with the moon , but what ? Hoping for a little science / biology in the answer as well . Metaphysics will definitely get my down - votes . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The human menstrual cycle, which is the period that most people are referring to when they say "period cycle," is typically around 28 days long. This is the time it takes for the body to go through the various changes and stages that are necessary for pregnancy to occur. 
The menstrual cycle is regulated by hormones produced by the body. These hormones, called estrogen and progesterone, help to control the growth and development of the uterine lining (the endometrium) and the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation). 
The length of the menstrual cycle can vary from person to person, but 28 days is considered to be the average length. There are many factors that can affect the length of the menstrual cycle, including stress, illness, certain medications, and changes in diet or exercise. 
The idea that the menstrual cycle is related to the moon is a myth. The moon has no direct effect on the menstrual cycle, although some people may experience changes in their cycle due to the body's natural circadian rhythms, which can be influenced by changes in light and darkness.

question: What actually happens when my 4 K tv up - scales a 1080p video to 4k video ? How is it able to increase resolution with such efficiency . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: One other thing to note is how the upscaling fills in the new pixels that have been added to the signal . There are several ways of doing this . One great way to see how your device upscales is by giving it a black and white checkerboard signal : BWBWBW ... WBWBWB ... BWBWBW ... : : : : : : : : : : : My first example is what has already been mentioned by others : BW WB turns into : BBWW BBWW WWBB WWBB Another method of upscaling tries to fill in the new pixels with averages of the surrounding pixels , in order to make the image appear " smoother " . As you 'll see , this usually only works on signal containing scenes of real images , and does not work so well on abstract images such as a checkerboard signal . BW WB turns into : BGWG GGGG WGBG GGGG In that example , the top - left pixel retains its original value , while the three new pixels get the average of the surrounding original pixels ( Grey in this case ) . It is arguable whether this is better or not , but I try not to think about it too much or I 'll go crazy . Source : Digital Media Certified Engineer Edit : Formatting

question: What actually happens when my 4 K tv up - scales a 1080p video to 4k video ? How is it able to increase resolution with such efficiency . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When your 4K TV upscales a 1080p video to 4K, it is using a process called "upsampling" to increase the resolution of the video. Essentially, the TV is taking the original 1080p video and adding additional pixels to the image to make it appear as if it has a higher resolution. 
To do this, the TV uses algorithms to guess what the additional pixels should look like based on the information in the original video. For example, if there is an object in the original video that is a solid color, the TV might use that information to fill in the additional pixels with the same color. If there is a gradient or pattern in the original video, the TV might use that information to create a smoother, more detailed gradient or pattern in the upscaled version. 
While upscaling can't actually increase the resolution of the original video, it can make the video look better on a 4K TV by adding more detail and making the image appear sharper. However, it's important to note that upscaled video will never look as good as native 4K video, as the additional pixels are just an approximation of what the higher resolution image should look like.

question: Why do some dinosaur bones stay as bones ( fossils ) , and others turn into petroleum ? What processes are happening with each scenario ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! Let's start with dinosaur bones. When a dinosaur dies, its bones are usually covered in dirt or sediment. This helps to protect the bones from being damaged by the environment, such as wind, rain, and sunlight. Over time, the sediment around the bones can harden into rock, and the bones can become fossilized. This means that the bones are preserved and can remain mostly unchanged for millions of years. 
Now, let's talk about petroleum. Petroleum is a type of fossil fuel that is formed from the remains of plants and animals that lived millions of years ago. When these plants and animals died, they were buried in sediment, just like dinosaur bones. However, instead of turning into fossils, the organic matter in the sediment underwent a series of chemical reactions over time. These reactions transformed the organic matter into a thick, black liquid called crude oil. Crude oil is the raw material used to make gasoline, diesel, and other products. 
So, in summary, dinosaur bones can become fossils if they are buried in sediment and protected from the environment. Petroleum is formed from the remains of plants and animals that are buried in sediment and undergo chemical reactions over time.

question: Why is alcohol withdrawal so intense to the point of being potentially fatal ? I tried to find an answer on google and found plenty on what the symptoms are , but could n't really find anything on why this is the case . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Alcohol withdrawal can be intense and potentially fatal because the body has become dependent on alcohol and needs it to function normally. When a person who has been drinking heavily stops drinking alcohol suddenly, their body can have a negative reaction because it is no longer receiving the substance it has become used to. This can cause the body to go into withdrawal, which can produce a range of symptoms such as tremors, seizures, and hallucinations. In severe cases, alcohol withdrawal can lead to delirium tremens, which is a condition that causes confusion, rapid heartbeat, and high fever. Delirium tremens can be life-threatening if left untreated. 
It's important to note that alcohol withdrawal can be managed and treated safely by medical professionals. If you or someone you know is experiencing alcohol withdrawal, it's important to seek medical help immediately.

question: How is Canadian healthcare different from Obamacare ? Canadian healthcare , along with many other countries who provide healthcare via the government , is working perfectly fine , so how is it working when American healthcare is n't ? Please explain like I'm five.

Canadian healthcare, also known as "Medicare," is a publicly funded healthcare system that provides universal coverage to all Canadian citizens and permanent residents. This means that all Canadian residents have access to a range of healthcare services, including hospital care, physician services, and prescription medications, at no direct cost to the patient. The healthcare system is funded through taxes paid by Canadians, and the services are provided by a combination of public and private hospitals and healthcare providers. 
Obamacare, also known as the Affordable Care Act (ACA), is a healthcare reform law that was passed in the United States in 2010. It was designed to make healthcare more accessible and affordable for Americans by expanding coverage to more people and requiring insurance companies to offer certain minimum benefits. However, unlike in Canada, the United States does not have a universal healthcare system, and many Americans still do not have access to affordable healthcare. Instead, the ACA relies on a combination of private insurance companies and government-funded programs, such as Medicaid, to provide coverage to Americans. 
There are a number of differences between the Canadian healthcare system and Obamacare. One of the main differences is that the Canadian system is universal, while the ACA only covers certain individuals. Another difference is that the Canadian system is funded through taxes, while the ACA relies on a combination of private insurance premiums and government funding. Finally, the Canadian system is administered by the government, while the ACA involves both private insurance companies and government programs.

Overall, the Rosetta mission was a big deal because it allowed scientists to learn more about comets and the early history of the solar system. It also showed that it is possible to land a spacecraft on a comet, which could open up new possibilities for future space missions.

question: What is the difference between a computer sleeping and hibernating ? If these could be juxtaposed that would be great ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Sleep : the computer is still " on " but in a low - power state so that it can resume normal operation within a few seconds . Usually you 'll just wiggle the mouse or press a key , and by the time your screen warms up the computer is good to go . Hibernate : the computer is " off " but saves its working state to the hard drive . The next time you turn the computer on , it will try to resume from almost exactly where it left off . Usually this will take a bit longer , possibly a few minutes . They 're similar . Compare sleeping for one night against hibernating for an entire season . Hibernating is a much deeper sleep , and you 're going to need more time to adjust once you do wake up .

question: What is the difference between a computer sleeping and hibernating ? If these could be juxtaposed that would be great ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When a computer is sleeping, it is in a low-power state where it can quickly wake up and start working again. This is useful if you plan to use the computer again soon, because it saves energy and allows you to start working faster. 
When a computer is hibernating, it is in a low-power state where it saves the current state of the computer to the hard drive and then turns off. This is useful if you are not going to use the computer for a longer period of time, because it saves more energy than sleeping and allows you to start working again exactly where you left off. 
To put it simply, sleeping is like taking a short nap, while hibernating is like going to bed for the night. Both can help save energy and make it easier to start using the computer again, but hibernating is a little more "serious" because it involves saving all your work and shutting down completely.

question: How X - rays are produced ? Studying A level physics , wondering if anyone can give me a clear explanation . Thank you . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
X-rays are a type of electromagnetic radiation, similar to light or radio waves. They have a shorter wavelength and higher frequency than visible light and are not visible to the human eye. 
To produce X-rays, a machine called an X-ray generator is used. The generator has an electron gun, which is a device that produces a stream of high-energy electrons. These electrons are accelerated through a tube inside the generator and are then directed towards a metal target, usually made of tungsten. 
As the high-energy electrons collide with the metal target, they release energy in the form of X-rays. This process is called bremsstrahlung, which means "braking radiation" in German. The X-rays produced by the generator are then directed towards the part of the body being examined, and they pass through the body and are captured on film or a digital detector on the other side. 
X-rays are used in many medical and industrial applications because they can pass through most materials and produce images of the inside of objects. They are particularly useful for examining bones, as they are absorbed by soft tissue but not by bone. This allows doctors to see the inside of the body and identify any problems or injuries.

question: Why is it so easy to save a word file as PDF but the opposite way is apparently complex ? If it wasn'nt for free online converters , I would have to PAY for it for Adobe Reader . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Saving a Word file as a PDF is easy because PDF (Portable Document Format) is a file format that was designed to be read on any device, regardless of the software or hardware used to create it. When you save a Word file as a PDF, you're essentially taking the contents of the Word file and converting them into a format that can be easily read and shared by anyone, even if they don't have Word or any other word processing software installed on their computer. 
On the other hand, converting a PDF back into a Word file can be more complex because a PDF doesn't contain the same kind of formatting and structure as a Word file. When you create a Word file, you can add things like headings, bullet points, tables, and other formatting elements that make it easy to organize and read the document. PDFs, on the other hand, are typically used for documents that are meant to be printed or shared as-is, rather than edited. So, when you try to convert a PDF back into a Word file, the software has to try to recreate all of those formatting elements and structure the document in a way that makes sense. This can be challenging, especially if the PDF contains a lot of complex formatting or images. 
That's why there are specialized tools, like Adobe Acrobat, that are designed specifically for converting PDFs into other formats. These tools can often do a better job of preserving the formatting and structure of the original PDF when converting it into a Word file or other editable format. However, these tools can also be expensive, which is why there are also free online converters that you can use to try to convert PDFs into Word files or other formats. These free tools may not be as powerful or accurate as the paid ones, but they can still be useful if you just need to make a few quick edits to a PDF.

question: The difference between murder/ assassination/ manslaughter I know the gist , and that they all may have gray areas to them , but I want to know the specific differences between them , if any . Update : Thank you all , this was very helpful . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! Here is a breakdown of the differences between murder, assassination, and manslaughter: 
Murder: Murder is the most serious of these crimes. It is the unlawful killing of another person with intent, or malice. This means that the person who committed the murder planned to kill the victim or acted with the intention of causing serious harm. Murder is usually punishable by life in prison or the death penalty, depending on the laws of the jurisdiction. 
Assassination: Assassination is a specific type of murder that involves killing someone for political reasons, such as to advance a political cause or to gain power. It is often carried out secretly and can involve a conspiracy, or group of people working together, to plan and execute the murder. 
Manslaughter: Manslaughter is a less serious crime than murder. It involves the unlawful killing of another person, but without the intention to kill. There are two main types of manslaughter: voluntary and involuntary. Voluntary manslaughter occurs when a person intentionally kills another person in the heat of the moment, often in response to some kind of provocation. Involuntary manslaughter occurs when a person unintentionally kills another person while engaging in reckless or negligent behavior. For example, if someone was driving while drunk and crashed their car, killing another person, they could be charged with involuntary manslaughter. Manslaughter is usually punishable by a prison sentence, but the length of the sentence will depend on the circumstances of the crime.

question: Since seedless fruit is essentially bred to be sterile ( no seeds to reproduce ) how would a farmer start a new plant of the spieces ? This might belong in /r / shittyaskscience , but I this is something I 've wondered for awhile . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are a few ways that farmers can propagate seedless fruits. One method is through a process called "grafting." This involves taking a piece of a mature fruit tree that is producing good fruit and attaching it to the root system of a young, healthy tree. The piece of the mature tree that is used is called a "scion," and the young tree is called the "rootstock." When the scion is grafted onto the rootstock, the rootstock provides the roots and base of the tree, while the scion provides the fruit-producing part of the tree. 
Another way that farmers can propagate seedless fruits is through a process called "cutting." This involves taking a cutting from a mature fruit tree and planting it in soil or water. The cutting will then begin to grow roots and eventually develop into a new tree. 
Seedless fruits can also be propagated through a process called "layering." This involves bending a low-growing branch of a fruit tree down to the ground and covering it with soil. As the branch begins to grow roots, it can be cut off from the parent tree and planted as a new tree. 
Finally, seedless fruits can also be propagated through a process called "micropropagation." This involves taking a small piece of tissue from a mature fruit tree and growing it in a laboratory setting. The tissue is placed in a special nutrient solution and allowed to grow into a new plant. Once the plant is large enough, it can be transferred to soil and grown into a full-sized tree.

When the blood flow is cut off, the cells in that area don't receive enough oxygen and nutrients. This can cause the cells to become damaged or die. As a result, the brain may interpret this as a sensation of pins and needles. 
The sensation of pins and needles is actually a way for the body to alert you that something is wrong and that you should move the limb to restore blood flow. If the limb stays in the same position for too long, it can lead to more serious problems, such as muscle damage or even nerve damage.

question: How are cathode ray tubes so precise on old TV 's ? I know what CRT 's are , I just wonder how the interpret the signal given and turn it into such a precise picture . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Cathode ray tubes (CRTs) are electronic devices that are used to display images on old television sets and computer monitors. They work by shooting a beam of electrons at a fluorescent screen, which then emits light to create the image. 
The beam of electrons is produced by a cathode, which is a negatively charged electrode located at the back of the CRT. The cathode is heated to a high temperature, which causes it to emit a stream of electrons. These electrons are then accelerated towards the front of the CRT by an electrical field. 
As the beam of electrons travels towards the front of the CRT, it passes through a series of deflection plates, which are electrical components that can change the direction of the beam. These deflection plates are controlled by the television signal, which tells them how to move the beam to create the desired image on the screen. 
The beam of electrons then hits the fluorescent screen, which is coated with a layer of phosphors. The phosphors are tiny particles that glow when struck by electrons. Different colors are produced by different types of phosphors, so the beam of electrons can create a range of colors on the screen by hitting different phosphors. 
Overall, CRTs are able to create precise images by using a beam of electrons that can be precisely controlled by the television signal to create the desired image on the screen.

question: Why do I have tonput the clutch down before braking / stopping I 'm learning to drive and I just do it but I do n't really know why . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When you are driving a manual transmission vehicle, the clutch is used to connect and disconnect the engine from the wheels. When you push the clutch pedal down, it disconnects the engine from the wheels, allowing you to change gears. 
When you are braking or coming to a stop, it's important to push the clutch down before you come to a complete stop. This is because if you leave the clutch engaged (not pressed down) while the car is stopped, it can cause the engine to stall. 
Stalling the engine can be inconvenient and potentially dangerous, especially if you are driving in heavy traffic or on a busy road. By pushing the clutch down before you come to a stop, you can avoid stalling the engine and ensure a smooth stop. 
It's also a good habit to get into because it can help you to smoothly shift into neutral when you come to a stop, rather than suddenly trying to find the right gear at the last minute. 
I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

question: What is the actual cause(s ) of death ( physiologically ) when someone burn to death(by fire ) ? For clarification I 'm talking about total immolation not being trapped in a house on fire and dying from smoke . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When someone burns to death, it means that their body is completely engulfed in flames and they sustain severe burns all over their body. The actual cause of death in this case is typically due to the combination of several factors, including: 
1. Smoke inhalation: When someone is on fire, they will inhale a lot of smoke, which can damage their airways and cause respiratory failure. 
2. Burns: Burns are a major cause of death in cases of immolation. Severe burns can cause the skin and underlying tissues to die, leading to organ failure and death. 
3. Shock: The body can go into shock due to the severe trauma and pain caused by the burns. Shock can cause a person's blood pressure to drop to dangerous levels, leading to organ failure and death. 
4. Asphyxiation: If the flames completely engulf the person's head and face, it can lead to asphyxiation (suffocation) due to the lack of oxygen. 
In summary, the actual cause of death in cases of immolation is usually a combination of smoke inhalation, burns, shock, and asphyxiation. These factors can cause severe damage to the body's tissues and organs, leading to organ failure and death.

question: Why do NFL team records fluctuate from year to year For example : Last year , Carolina Panthers and New Orleanse Saints were 12 - 4 and 11 - 5 . But this year , they are currently both 5 - 8 . Please explain like I'm five.

There are many factors that can contribute to a team's record fluctuating from year to year in the NFL. 
One reason is that each team has a roster of players, and the players on a team can change from year to year. For example, a team might lose some of their best players to injury or to other teams, or they might bring in new players through the draft or free agency. When a team has a lot of changes to their roster, it can take time for the new players to get used to playing together and for the team to find their rhythm. This can lead to a team's record fluctuating. 
Another reason is that each team plays a different schedule of games each year. One year, a team might have a lot of tough opponents and have a harder time winning games. The next year, they might have an easier schedule and have more success. 
There are also many other factors that can affect a team's performance, such as the coaching staff, the team's overall strategy and game plan, and the overall level of talent and depth on the team. All of these factors can contribute to a team's record fluctuating from year to year.

question: Why to the label wood 2"x4"/ 2"x6 " / 2"x8 " etc when the true measurements are irregular and actually 1.75"x3.5 " and so on * they Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The labels on lumber, such as "2x4" or "2x6", refer to the rough size of the wood before it has been planed smooth or finished. The rough size is the size of the wood as it comes straight from the sawmill or lumber mill, and it includes the bark and rough edges of the wood. The rough size is usually larger than the actual finished size of the wood, which is the size of the wood after it has been planed smooth and all of the rough edges have been removed. 
So, when a piece of wood is labeled as a "2x4", it means that it is roughly 2 inches thick and 4 inches wide, but the actual finished size of the wood will be slightly smaller, around 1.75 inches thick and 3.5 inches wide. This is because some of the rough, unfinished wood must be removed during the finishing process in order to create a smooth, finished surface. 
I hope this helps to explain why the labels on lumber don't always match the actual finished size of the wood.

question: How did humans learn to extract metal from rocks ? This is something that has always perplexed me . How the hell did our ancestors learn that putting certain types of rocks in 2000 degree furnaces would yield a useful material for weapons and tools ? Please explain like I'm five.

It is a pretty likely accident , putting a rock in a fire , getting weird metals , then looking for more rocks that did the same . Copper is too hot to smelt in a campfire , but came along about the same time as pottery kilns , so it probably was discovered the same way lead and tin were . From the idea of " hotter fire = better metal " emerges pretty naturally , allow silver , gold , and eventually iron smelting to be discovered .

question: How did humans learn to extract metal from rocks ? This is something that has always perplexed me . How the hell did our ancestors learn that putting certain types of rocks in 2000 degree furnaces would yield a useful material for weapons and tools ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The process of extracting metal from rocks, or ore, is called smelting. Humans have been smelting metals for thousands of years. 
To extract metal from ore, we need to heat it up to a very high temperature. This is because the metal is mixed in with other elements and we need to separate it. To do this, we put the ore in a special furnace called a smelter. The smelter is like a really hot oven that can reach temperatures of over 2000 degrees Fahrenheit. 
When we heat the ore in the smelter, the metal becomes a liquid. This is because the heat makes the metal particles move faster and they start to break away from the other elements in the ore. The metal then flows to the bottom of the smelter and collects in a special container called a crucible. 
Once the metal has cooled and solidified, we can take it out of the crucible and use it to make things like weapons and tools. 
It's not exactly clear how humans first figured out this process, but it's likely that they learned through trial and error. They may have noticed that certain types of rocks produced a shiny, metallic substance when they were heated, and they experimented with different methods to extract and purify the metal.

" As for getting the food in your mouth , that 's just a matter of getting a food that clumps together pretty well , directing it to your mouth , " Here comes the airplane , " and then nom . question: How do people eat and drink in space ? would n't the food just float around and not go straight to the stomach ? something i 've always wanted to know Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Eating and drinking in space can be a bit different from how we do it on Earth. Because there is no gravity in space, food and drinks don't stay in one place like they do on Earth. This can make it a bit tricky to eat and drink, because the food and drinks can float around and be hard to hold onto. 
To eat in space, astronauts use special utensils that are designed to be used in zero gravity. These utensils are often attached to the food packaging or to a tray so they don't float away. The food itself is also often packed in special containers that are easy to open and eat from in space. 
Drinking in space can be a bit trickier, because liquids tend to float around and can be hard to control. To drink in space, astronauts use special containers with straws or tubes that they can suck on to get the liquid to flow into their mouths. They also have to be careful not to drink too much at once, because the liquid could float out of their mouths and make a mess. 
Overall, eating and drinking in space requires some special tools and techniques, but it's not too different from how we do it on Earth. It just takes a little bit of practice to get used to it!

question: What 's the worst an identity thief could do if they somehow stole my social security number but nothing else ? I always hear this as a cautionary piece of advice regarding my internet habits but it seems dubious . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: I work in big data and identity theft protection , this is my field of expertise ! * * Assuming they only have the SSN * * A social security number by itself is useless . The only thing you can learn from a social security number is the year and location of issuance . This information can be gathered from the High Group List . If the SSN was issued after June 2011 , you ca n't use the HGL on it anymore ( the SSA started [ SSN randomization ] ( URL_5 ) ) . You can also check to see if the holder is deceased or not . This information used to be published monthly by the SSA : name , ssn , dob , dod , last known zipcode , and " proof code " . This was called the Death Master File ( DMF ) . The SSA used to publish this monthly in the name of fraud prevention ( they did n't want anyone using recently deceased information to take out loans and such ) . Last year they stopped publishing this information - again in the name of " fraud prevention " - because nobody was taking advantage of the DMF when issuing loans . The only people who ever used it were the criminals . Now they wait a year or two before publishing any of the deceased info . * * Assuming they have more than the SSN * * Data thieves work by following leads - just like a detective . If you have a name and SSN , you 're almost always able to get MORE information . Just follow the thread and employ a bit of social engineering . The easiest thing to do with your name and SSN is to e - file your taxes for you with bogus wages . I tell the IRS that I want a debit card with my refund on it and I get away with your tax return . * * You can prevent this by requesting a PIN from the IRS . * * Even if you do n't think you have been or will be targeted , get a PIN from the IRS . This prevents people from filing your taxes for you and getting a bogus refund . What else can I do with your name and SSN ? Well , I * probably * know where you live ( I can use the high group list and hope you never moved or I can do an internet search to find your online profiles - especially if you have a unique name ) . From there , I can likely find your address . There are TONS of people finding websites out there which use public " consumer " data . I 'll go into that more later . A perfect example is [ PeopleSmart ] ( URL_4 ) ( not the best data , but you get the idea ) . Again , this is PUBLIC DATA . All I have to do in order to get lots of info on you is pay for it . Most places will charge 10 - 50 bucks per report . What 's in a report ? Name , DOB , address history , phone numbers , relatives , criminal records , BLJ records ( bankruptcies , liens , and judgements ) , vehicle registration records , voter registration records , professional licenses , employment history ( though that 's getting harder to find these days ) , and the list goes on . Now I have everything I 'll ever need to destroy your life . I can have IDs made in your name - which is not hard for a criminal ( just head over to /r / fakeid ) . Or I can get REAL ids from the state agencies by pretending to be you . Lots of agencies will issue a new ID if you show them a bill with your name on it ( I 'll just stop by your house while you 're at work , steal a bill out of your mail , head to the DMV and claim to be you ) . So now I 've got all your information and valid ( or fake ) IDs in your name . What next ? Apply for credit cards , loans , and services in your name . I max them out and leave you to pay the bills . * * What are the best ways to prevent this ? * * - * * Get credit monitoring * * . Most banks offer this for a small monthly fee ( 5 - 10 bucks ) . It will not STOP someone from applying for credit in your name , but it will alert you when it does happen . If you can stop it before it goes too far , you 're likely to come out of this clean . If you let it go on for months , it 's a lot harder to prove that you 're the victim of ID fraud . - * * Get a filing PIN from the IRS * * . This prevents people from filing your taxes for you and getting a refund . It 's VERY easy to do - just google " irs filing pin " and you 'll be well on your way . If you forget your PIN , you just need to visit the local taxation office ( most states have a few of them ) . - * * Do n't opt - in . * * I mentioned " consumer data " earlier . Consumer data is data that 's collected from companies that you buy stuff from . Magazine subscriptions , online services , credit cards , loans , etc . Have you ever noticed that once you get a magazine subscription , suddenly you get tons of junk mail for other magazines ? Well , people buy this consumer data in bulk and look for people who recently bought magazines , put them in a mailing list , and dispatch the spam . Your profile consists of TONS of metrics . This includes your personal info ( name , address , phone , dob , etc ) , your property data ( own vs rent , house vs apartment , pool / no pool , central heating ? , number of fireplaces ? number of bedrooms ? etc ) , your hobbies and interests , the number of children you have ( and their ages ) , the number of pets you have , and just about anything else that you might learn about a person while taking a 101 language course . * * So what do you do ? * * Sign up for these services with fake information . Need to buy something online ? Use a prepaid debit card . And READ THE PRIVACY POLICY ! - * * Opt - out * * . Almost every website that sells consumer data will allow you to opt - out of their databases . If they do n't , send them a letter in the mail requesting an opt - out . If they ignore , get a lawyer to sign it . Most websites have an online form that lets you do this . [ Here 's a link to PeopleSmart 's ] ( URL_1 ) . The problem with this is that there are TONS of websites out there with your information . You could spend years doing it . Luckily there are a lot of services that will automate this process for you . Someone on reddit also made a link to the biggest ones and their opt - out forms : [ link ] ( URL_3 ) - * * Do n't give information that 's not necessary ! * * Lots of doctors offices , banks , and other places will ask for your SSN but they do n't actually NEED it . Leave it blank and only fill it in if they can explain to you why they need it . Legally , the only people who can * * require * * your SSN are the IRS . - * * Call The Big 3 * * ( TransUnion , Equifax , and Experian - and increasingly Lexis ) . They will NOT remove ID theft activity from your credit report unless you fight them . Eventually they will remove it ( especially if you have a lawyer ) but they 'll resist a LOT before they do . They 'll tell you that they 're just " reporting what has been reported to them " and " our credit scores only reflect the data " and other BS . Do n't give up ! The bigger the company , the more fuss they 'll make . - * * Get a police report ! * * Contact the FTC , attorney general , and SSA . The FTC will be one of your biggest allies throughout your battle , believe it or not . Most of them wo n't do crap without a police report , though - especially the SSA . After enough noise , the SSA will give you a new SSN , but you must prove that the SSN was actually USED . - * * Get your criminal records expunged ASAP * * Most courts offer this for free ( or a small fee ) if the record is over a certain age . Background check companies scrape county courthouse websites ALL THE TIME to gather these records . If your data is expunged , you can sue anyone who does not remove the record from their website ( though you have to give them a 2 week notice , usually ) . - * * Move out of Florida * * No joke , Florida sells EVERY bit of residential information they possibly can . They sell it all to data companies for extra revenue . Most states sell this information , but not all of it . Florida is the worst . Hunting licenses , fishing licenses , driving records , criminal records , voter registration records , all of it . - * * Do n't register to vote * * ( or if you do , URGE your congressmen to stop selling voter registration data ) . Voter registration data is sold in most states in bulk . It includes name , phone number , party affiliation , address , and DOB ( though a lot of them are now trying to only give the year of birth ) . Some states GIVE this information away for free . [ Ohio has a search feature for it ] ( URL_0 ) ( they used to just dump it all on an FTP for free ) . Most states make you fill out a form and pay a few hundred bucks for the data , though . * * Edit :* * If you have any other questions , * * please contact me * * . I really do n't mind answering questions about this . I honestly know more about the data end , but I 've been in this field for 5 years now and have learned a LOT through experience . I 'd be happy to explain more about how the data gets bought and sold from one company to the next ( that 's mostly what I do ) . * * Edit 2 :* * Just thought I 'd mention who 's who in this world of data selling . Some of the biggest data - resellers ( bulk data ) are Acxiom and InfoUSA . Acxiom sells mostly online data ( they do customer tracking using IP addresses and cookies and then link it up to your real world profile for advertisers ) . InfoUSA sells demographic info for mailing lists . Looking for all the single mothers with 2 children and 3 dogs in zipcodes with less than 1000 residents ? That 's the kind of targeted mail - advertising InfoUSA offers . Though they do n't do the mailing themselves - they just sell the data . Background check companies are huge . There 's too many to count ! BeenVerified has decent data , URL_2 has subpar data , TLO ( now Transunion ) has excellent data , and I ca n't really speak for the others that much . Everyone else has scraped data . * * Edit 3 :* * Added a few new bullet points above

question: How come our eyes ca n't look in different directions at the same time ? I 'm sure there is a reason for this ... what is it ? You 'd think it 'd be beneficial to see in two separate directions at the same time . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Basically we ca n't because our primordial ancestors could n't . The mechanism to do so does n't exist in humans , apes , or most other mammals for that matter . While it might be a benefit to chameleons and some birds ( who may or may not be capable of it , I do n't know for sure ) our brains just are n't set up to process that kind of input . Binocular vision in hunting animals relies on the brain being able to estimate distance to prey . Having our eyes looking at two different things at once would kill our depth perception .

question: How come our eyes ca n't look in different directions at the same time ? I 'm sure there is a reason for this ... what is it ? You 'd think it 'd be beneficial to see in two separate directions at the same time . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Our eyes are designed to focus on one thing at a time, which helps us see things clearly. If our eyes could move independently and look in different directions at the same time, it would be difficult for our brains to process the information and make sense of it. Instead, our eyes are able to move together in a coordinated way, allowing us to focus on one thing and see it clearly. This helps us see the world around us more effectively and makes it easier for our brains to understand what we're looking at.

question: How do developers make " better " compression algorithms ? What do we know or do now that we did n't when we first started file compression ? What makes new image and video codecs better than their predecessors ? Please explain like I'm five.

When you see a new algorithm start getting used , that usually just means that modern computers have improved to the point where they have the resources to practically compress & extract data with a better algorithm .

question: How do developers make " better " compression algorithms ? What do we know or do now that we did n't when we first started file compression ? What makes new image and video codecs better than their predecessors ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Developers make "better" compression algorithms by finding ways to compress data more efficiently. This means that they are able to reduce the size of the data while still maintaining the same quality. There are a few different ways that they can do this. 
One way is by finding more efficient ways to represent the data. For example, instead of representing each pixel in an image as a separate piece of information, they might use patterns or colors to represent groups of pixels. This can help to reduce the amount of data that needs to be stored. 
Another way is by finding more efficient ways to compress the data. This might involve using algorithms that are more efficient at finding patterns in the data, or using techniques like predictive coding to better estimate what data is most important to keep. 
Finally, developers can also make new codecs (compression algorithms for audio and video) better by improving the way that they handle different types of data. For example, they might create codecs that are better at compressing video with a lot of fast-moving action, or codecs that are better at compressing audio with a wide range of frequencies. 
Overall, the goal of compression algorithms is to reduce the amount of data that needs to be stored or transmitted, while still maintaining the quality of the original data. As technology and our understanding of data compression improve, we are able to create more efficient algorithms that can compress data even more effectively.

question: Hypnotism . How does it work , why does it work and where can I learn ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Hypnosis does n't exactly work like people imagine it to work , there is no trance state . Everything is about the power of suggestions and the suspension of disbelief . About 1/5 of the population are what we call highly suggestible . Through a series of physical tricks we can narrow down an audience to see who is the most receptive to suggestion and then we exploit that on stage . Hypnosis in a clinical setting it is similar but it takes longer depending on the person , there is a series of tasks that essentially associates what the hypnotist says with reality until the lines blur and what the hypnotist says becomes their reality . I started studying it as a progression from street magic and have done a lot of hypnosis in bar settings but I 've not done anything clinical or sexual .

question: Hypnotism . How does it work , why does it work and where can I learn ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Hypnotism, also known as hypnosis, is a method of inducing a trance-like state in a person in order to alter their behavior, thoughts, or feelings. It is often used in therapy to help people overcome problems such as anxiety, phobias, and pain. 
During hypnosis, a person is typically asked to focus their attention on a particular object or thought, and to relax their body and mind. The hypnotist may also use certain techniques such as repeating a specific phrase or making suggestions to the person while they are in this relaxed state. 
The exact reason why hypnosis works is not fully understood, but it is thought that it may help a person to bypass their conscious mind and access their subconscious mind, where habits, memories, and emotions are stored. This can allow the hypnotist to make suggestions or give commands that the person may be more receptive to, or to help the person access and overcome negative thoughts or behaviors. 
There are many places where you can learn about hypnosis and how to use it. You can find books on the subject at a library or bookstore, or you can search online for articles and videos about hypnosis. Some schools and universities also offer courses on hypnosis, and there are professional organizations that offer certification programs for people who want to learn how to use hypnosis in a therapeutic setting.

Overall, the appearance of a space shuttle moving slowly during launch is an optical illusion caused by the distance between the viewer and the shuttle, as well as the size of the shuttle itself.

question: why does the flat circle coin seem to be the universal shape of currency , why did n't it take other shapes ? Why not cubes ? Edit : or spheres , why not spheres ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: three reasons ; efficiency in minting them and wear resistance . A flat coin is much easier to mint than a cube . Nowadays you start with a flat roll of metal and punch out disks . Previously , you could pour molten metal into open faced circular molds . Three dimensional shapes ( such as cubes ) could not as easily be punched out or cast . Meanwhile , anything with sharp corners will tend to have those corners beat up rather quickly . So squares are out , those nice distinct corners would get damaged really quickly . Octagons and other many sided shapes are sometimes used because the less distinct corners tend to get rounded off slower .

question: why does the flat circle coin seem to be the universal shape of currency , why did n't it take other shapes ? Why not cubes ? Edit : or spheres , why not spheres ? Please explain like I'm five.

The shape of coins and other forms of currency is largely a matter of tradition and practicality. Coins have been used as a form of currency for thousands of years, and over time, certain shapes have become standard. 
One reason that round coins are so common is that they are easy to make using simple tools. It is relatively simple to cut a round coin out of a flat sheet of metal, and the coin can be easily rolled if it needs to be transported. In contrast, it would be much more difficult to cut a cube or a sphere out of metal using basic tools. 
Another reason that round coins are so common is that they are easy to stack and store. If you have a pile of round coins, they will naturally fit together in a way that makes it easy to count them and keep track of how much money you have. Coins of other shapes might not stack as easily, which could make them more difficult to use. 
In summary, round coins are common because they are easy to make, easy to transport, and easy to store. While it is possible that currency could be made in other shapes, round coins have become the standard due to their practicality and longstanding tradition.

question: Why do we need standoffs on our motherboards ? Couple of months ago , I fucked up my motherboard by not installing standoffs . The computer guy told me it caused a short circuit , but I never understood why . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Standoffs are used to physically separate the motherboard from the case of a computer. This separation is important for a number of reasons. 
First, the motherboard and the case are made of different materials, and they can have different electrical charges. If the motherboard is in contact with the case, these charges can flow between the two, causing a short circuit. Standoffs help to prevent this by providing a physical barrier between the motherboard and the case. 
Second, standoffs help to support the motherboard and keep it level within the case. This can help to prevent the motherboard from bending or warping due to the weight of the components that are attached to it. 
Finally, standoffs also help to provide airflow within the case by creating space between the motherboard and the case. This can help to keep the components on the motherboard cooler, which can help to extend their lifespan. 
In short, standoffs are an important component of a computer case because they help to protect the motherboard from damage, support it, and improve airflow.

There are a few reasons why your phone might be correcting "hell" to "he'll" but not correcting "s" to "a": 
1. The predictive texting algorithm may have learned that you frequently type "he'll" and therefore suggests it more often.

3. The algorithm might be programmed to prioritize correcting common spelling mistakes over correcting less common ones. In this case, "s" instead of "a" might be considered a less common mistake, so the algorithm doesn't correct it as frequently. 
It's important to note that predictive texting algorithms are not perfect and can sometimes make mistakes or suggest words that don't make sense. If you don't want the algorithm to make suggestions, you can usually turn off the predictive texting feature in your phone's settings.
