I do n't think the film presents his actions as good , or anything other than " unbridled lust / rage " at all . The film asks questions about how far it is ethical to go to " fix " people . In the film , Alex is forcibly rehabilitated with classical conditioning , forcing him to go through extreme pain for a very long period of time , with the end result of one of his favorite things in the world ( classical music ) being physically painful for him , because it was part of the technique used to torture him and make him " better " .

question: What is all the fuss about a Clockwork Orange , and what is the message about it I am missing ? The only thing I can see is the raw , unbridled lust / rage , contrast to 9 to 5 life is truly being alive ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
A Clockwork Orange is a novel written by Anthony Burgess and later adapted into a film directed by Stanley Kubrick. The story follows the life of a young man named Alex, who is a delinquent and enjoys committing acts of violence and crime. He is eventually arrested and undergoes an experimental form of rehabilitation that aims to cure him of his violent tendencies. 
The fuss around A Clockwork Orange is due to the controversial themes and ideas that it explores. One of the main themes of the novel and film is the nature of free will and the consequences of trying to control or manipulate it. The story raises questions about whether it is ethical to try to change someone's behavior through means such as brainwashing, and whether it is possible to truly reform someone who has engaged in violent or criminal behavior. 
Another theme of the story is the idea that true freedom involves the ability to choose between good and evil, and that taking away this choice removes an essential aspect of what makes us human. The novel and film also explore the theme of the dangers of a society that becomes too focused on order and control, and the potential for this to lead to a loss of personal freedom and individuality. 
Overall, the message of A Clockwork Orange might be seen as a cautionary tale about the dangers of trying to control or manipulate people's behavior, and the importance of preserving individual freedom and choice.

question: Why is n't it considered corruption when politicians grant access to lobbyists in return for financial gain . EDIT : Since lobbyists give campaign donations and receive access to politicians in return , why is n't this considered corruption ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Hi- I 've been a registered lobbyist in the US so I can give you a perspective different than most of the others here . First , when a lobbyist gives money , they 're probably not giving their own money . Instead , they they are giving money from a Political Action Committee which collects money from other donors . Corporations can also have corporate PACs . This is important because lobbyists are speaking on behalf of others . In the US there is a constitutional right to petition government . Donating to political campaigns is also recognized an as expression of free speech . The US also has a strong tradition of legal representation -- Americans generally want a lawyer to advise them on issues in the courtroom whereas in some other , often authoritarian countries , you do n't have that luxury and are forced to navigate a complex legal system you do nt understand by yourself . So when a lobbyist donates money to a politicians campaign , they are ( 1 ) assisting donors to exercise their freedom of speech and ( 2 ) assisting donors to petition their government . Lobbyists are specialists , just like plumbers or lawyers . They understand the byzantine way that a government works and they can provide expert advice about what is realistic , what is ethical and how to accomplish a goal . So , now the question is , does money equal access . The answer , based on a long history of studies is -- yes . Money does get you access . But you can also get access when you do n't give money . And you can be ignored even if you do give money . Getting in the door is really hard and really important . I ca n't tell you how many hours I 've spent just trying to figure out how to get into a room . That said , getting into a room does n't get you anything more than face time . I 've sat across a coffee table from members of congress who loathed the group I represented . Being in their presence did n't get me anything ( other than making conservative members of my group happy that i reached out ) . I do not agree that corruption is getting in the room . It does n't actually get you anything . Getting something is ... well ... getting something . And yes , you do see that some companies are able to getting everything that they want from certain members of congress , but the reality is that * * they were bought and sold before they even ran for office . * * Another thing -- if you talk to lobbyists , a large percentage , i 'd say half , will say that money really does ruin politics . I personally believe in 100 % public financed campaigns and a prohibition on any contribution or in kind contribution . It will never happen , and the reason is not because politicians wo n't let it happen . The reason is that the public wo n't let it happen . Politicians are n't any different than anyone else . They 're just a reflection that people do n't like to see .

question: Why is n't it considered corruption when politicians grant access to lobbyists in return for financial gain . EDIT : Since lobbyists give campaign donations and receive access to politicians in return , why is n't this considered corruption ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Lobbying is a legitimate way for businesses, organizations, and individuals to try to influence decisions made by government officials, such as lawmakers. Lobbyists may give campaign donations to politicians in order to gain access to them and present their viewpoints on issues that are important to them. While this type of activity may be seen as potentially influencing a politician's decision-making, it is not necessarily considered corruption. 
Corruption is generally defined as the abuse of power or position for personal gain. In the context of lobbying, if a politician were to grant special favors or take specific actions in exchange for campaign donations or other forms of personal gain, that would be considered corruption. However, simply receiving campaign donations and allowing lobbyists to present their viewpoints does not necessarily constitute corruption. It is important for politicians to be transparent about their interactions with lobbyists and to disclose any campaign donations they receive in order to ensure that the process is fair and aboveboard.

question: Why do drugs make our eyes look different ? why do we experience dilated pupils , red eyes , glossy eyes , low eyes ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: It depends on what the drug is . Cannabis , for example , causes blood vessels in your eyes to expand slightly , which makes them more visible . Some people also get it from mild allergies to something in the plant . Drugs that cause increases of seratonin levels ( cocaine , LSD , MDMA ) cause dilation . Seratonin stimulates the 5 - HT2A receptor . It has an inhibitory effect on areas in your visual cortex . I suspect its inhibiting the ability of the sphincter muscles that constrict your iris to work . More simply , drugs like LSD cause a bunch of a chemical to pool in your brain that shuts of the iris constriction muscles . Some drugs increase norepinephrine levels , including cocaine and meth . This stimulates the sympathetic nervous system , causing the " fight or flight " response . One of these responses is the dilation of the pupils . This uses the iris dilator muscle , which does the opposite of the sphincter muscle and pushes the iris open . Opiates cause pupil constriction . I ca n't find the exact mechanism , but I believe it stimulates the parasympathetic nervous system , which is sorta like the opposite of the " fight or flight " response . I also just found that dextromethorphan ( DXM ) acts on the parasympathetic nervous system , so I would also expect it to cause constriction , though I do n't know for sure . Glassy eyes are caused by drugs that depress the central nervous system . One reason this happens is that you blink less if your nervous system gets turned down . This appearance is exacerbated by pupil dilation . ELI5 summary : Red eyes are caused by blood vessel expansion . Dilation is caused either by the brain shutting down the constriction muscles or by turning on the dilation muscles , depending . Constriction is caused by the brain activating the constriction muscles . Glassy eyes are caused by eyes drying out and pupil dilation .

question: Why do drugs make our eyes look different ? why do we experience dilated pupils , red eyes , glossy eyes , low eyes ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! When you take drugs, they can affect the way your body works and feels. Different drugs can have different effects on your body, including your eyes. 
Dilated pupils: Pupils are the small, black circles in the center of your eyes that control how much light enters your eyes. When you take certain drugs, your pupils may get bigger, or dilated. This is because the drug is affecting the muscles around your pupils, causing them to relax and open wider. 
Red eyes: Some drugs can make your eyes red because they can cause blood vessels in your eyes to become larger and more visible. This can also happen if you smoke certain drugs, like marijuana. 
Glossy eyes: Glossy eyes can happen when a person takes drugs that cause their eyes to feel dry or produce less tears. Without enough tears, the surface of the eye may look glossy or shiny. 
Low eyes: Low, or droopy, eyes can happen when a person takes drugs that relax the muscles around their eyes. This can cause the eyelids to feel heavy and droop down. 
It's important to remember that drugs can have many different effects on the body and can be dangerous to use. If you have any concerns about drugs and their effects, it's a good idea to talk to a trusted adult or a healthcare professional.

question: How did planets form to have their own gravitational pull ? Why is the core so hot ? Just thinking about planet formation . How do these massive things even stick together ? How did a gravitational pull in a single location built mass that became a planet ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Ok first question : Everything has a gravitational pull . Not just planets . You have a gravitational pull and so does your cat and your socks . Everything with mass is constantly pulling on everything else with Mass no matter how far they are . This continues to happen until you get planets . In some cases the planets get so massive that their gravitational pull is stronger than the forces keeping atoms far apart and then the sun will collapse into a black hole . Second question : > There are three main sources of heat in the deep earth : ( 1 ) heat from when the planet formed and accreted , which has not yet been lost ; ( 2 ) frictional heating , caused by denser core material sinking to the center of the planet ; and ( 3 ) heat from the decay of radioactive elements .

question: How did planets form to have their own gravitational pull ? Why is the core so hot ? Just thinking about planet formation . How do these massive things even stick together ? How did a gravitational pull in a single location built mass that became a planet ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! So, planets form from the leftover material that was left over after the sun formed. This material was made up of gas, dust, and small rocks. When the sun formed, it was so hot that it blew most of the gas away, but some of the dust and small rocks stuck together because of their own gravitational pull. 
As more and more of these small pieces stuck together, they formed bigger and bigger clumps. Eventually, these clumps became big enough to be called planets. The bigger the planet, the stronger its gravitational pull, which is why it can hold onto more material and grow even bigger. 
The core of a planet is hot because it is made up of very heavy elements, such as iron and nickel, which are denser and heavier than the other materials that make up the planet. When the planet was forming, these heavy elements sank to the center of the planet and formed the core. The heat in the core comes from the pressure of all of the material above it, as well as the heat that was generated when the planet was forming.

question: If Japan knew that it could not win a protracted war with the US , why did they attack in WWII ? What benefit could they possibly have seen in attacking Hawaii ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: They did n't think the war would be protracted . By crippling the Pacific Fleet , they bought time to fortify their positions . They figured that the cost to retake the lost territory would be too high for the Americans to stomach . As for why they attacked at all , Japan was between a rock and a hard place . The US had an embargo against Japan , and was starving it of vital resources ( primarily oil iirc ) that it needed to continue the war effort in China . Further , the US was a very powerful force built up in the Pacific , and the two countries * were * going to come into conflict sooner or later , and if they waited for the Americans to make the first move , it could have been a catastrophe . So the tl;dr is this : go in for a cheap shot early , bide time to bulk up defenses , and hope that the Americans just accept the loss of some minor overseas possessions instead of mobilizing for total war . It was a mistaken calculation , but not totally irrational .

question: If Japan knew that it could not win a protracted war with the US , why did they attack in WWII ? What benefit could they possibly have seen in attacking Hawaii ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Japan attacked the US in WWII because they were trying to expand their empire and gain more resources. At the time, the US had a large military presence in the Pacific, and Japan saw attacking the US as a way to try to weaken that presence and gain more control in the region. The attack on Hawaii, which was a surprise attack on the US naval base at Pearl Harbor, was part of this effort to try to damage the US military's ability to defend itself and its interests in the Pacific. Japan likely hoped that by attacking the US, they could convince the US to retreat from the region and allow Japan to continue to expand its empire without interference.

question: Why are prescribed burns good for the environment ? This is the result of one this weekend .. URL_0 Win for the forest , loose for air quality . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: First , it clears out a lot of dead and about to be dead trees , bushes , etc . that are n't doing anything but sitting there , waiting to become fuel for a summer wildfire . If you burn some of that stuff out when the weather is such that you can control it , it 's much less of a problem than if it contributes to an uncontrolled fire in hot weather , when the ashes could float away and set more fires , possibly miles away.(it would surprise you just how hot a piece of ash carried off in the wind can be , and how long it could stay hot ) Second , when that burns down , it leaves ash and charcoal behind . That stuff is carbon , and precipitation will cause that carbon to leech into the soil . This is very good for the soil , it makes the new vegetation grow well . question: Why are prescribed burns good for the environment ? This is the result of one this weekend .. URL_0 Win for the forest , loose for air quality . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Prescribed burns are a way of intentionally setting fire to a specific area in a controlled and planned manner. They are often used as a tool for managing forests and grasslands. 
There are several reasons why prescribed burns can be good for the environment: 
1. Prescribed burns can reduce the risk of uncontrolled wildfires. Wildfires can be extremely destructive and dangerous, and they can be difficult to control once they start. By conducting prescribed burns, land managers can reduce the amount of dry, dead vegetation that can fuel a wildfire, which can help to prevent future fires from spreading out of control. 
2. Prescribed burns can improve habitat for wildlife. Many plants and animals depend on fire to maintain their habitats. For example, some plants have seeds that only germinate after a fire, and some animals rely on the open, grassy areas created by burns for foraging and nesting. 
3. Prescribed burns can improve the health of forests and grasslands. Over time, dead plants and debris can build up on the forest floor, which can make it difficult for new plants to grow. Prescribed burns can help to clear out this debris, which can allow new plants to take root and thrive. 
4. Prescribed burns can also help to improve air quality. When vegetation is burned, it releases smoke and other particles into the air. question: What gives atoms their various properties ? Glancing at the period table I can discern no pattern . Can you predict what behaviour an atom will have because of the balance of subatomic particles in the system ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Yes , broadly speaking . Atoms gain their properties due to their valence . Learning about this is basically most of the first semester of a college chemistry course , but the short version is : Atoms are basically clouds of electrons surrounding a core of protons and neutrons . The clouds of electrons behave in a way that is random , but overall very predictable , and they try to form a pattern that resembles a shell of electrons composed of sets of four pairs to make an octet . Bigger atoms have many shells of eight , smaller ones may have only one ( or fewer than one complete shell ) but it 's only the outermost shell that really matters for bonding and chemical properties . When two elements bond , they share an electron or two to fulfil their octets . Different atoms as you go down a row of the periodic table have different numbers of valience electrons in their outermost shell . These are what make atoms react differently . Lithium , sodium , potassium , etc , have one atom in their outermost valience shell - that means they want to bond very much with something that can fill their shell . If you put sodium in water , it rips the water apart , and causes an explosion as the oxygen and hydrogen heat up . Likewise , flourine , chlorine , iodine , etc , all have seven electrons in their outer shell - they want badly to fill with things with only one electron , like hydrogen . That 's why these elements can make such powerful acids - it 's very easy for them to steal a hydrogen from water . Carbon has four electons . It ( and silicon , to a lesser degree ) is the whore of the elemnts . It loves to bond with a lot of stuff becuase there 's so many ways it can make pairs . Oxygen has six , so it loves to double bond ( share two pairs of electrons ) with carbon , or one each with hydrogen ( to make water . ) Finally the nobel gasses come complete with eight already . That 's why they hardly ever bond with * anything * . There 's more to this explanation than just that - radioactivity , transition elements , metals , different levels of valence shells , different types of bonds , subatomic forces , resonance , etc , but that is basically an entire chem course worth of information . But valence electrons are the most important thing overall .

question: What gives atoms their various properties ? Glancing at the period table I can discern no pattern . Can you predict what behaviour an atom will have because of the balance of subatomic particles in the system ? Please explain like I'm five.

The properties of an atom are determined by the arrangement of its electrons. The electrons are arranged in shells around the nucleus, and each shell can hold a certain number of electrons. The outermost shell is called the valence shell, and the number of electrons in the valence shell determines how the atom will behave. 
If an atom has a full valence shell, it is stable and not very reactive. Atoms that have only a few electrons in their valence shell, on the other hand, are more reactive because they want to gain more electrons to fill their valence shell. This is why some elements, like sodium and chlorine, are very reactive: they have only one or a few electrons in their valence shells and are eager to gain or lose those electrons to become more stable. 
So to sum up: the number of protons in an atom's nucleus determines what element it is, and the arrangement of electrons around the nucleus determines the atom's properties.

Now imagine that the ladder is slowly turning around. The stars are still there, but they seem to move in the sky as you change your perspective. 
The same thing happens with the constellations. The Earth is moving around the sun, and the sun is moving around the galaxy, so the stars seem to move in the sky. But because the Earth takes a whole year to go around the sun, and the sun takes even longer to go around the galaxy, it takes a long time for the constellations to change. So, even though the constellations are always moving, it's hard for us to notice the changes because they happen so slowly.

question: Why are n't animals given a vasectomy instead of being neutered ? It seems like it would be much more humane Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are a few reasons why veterinarians usually prefer to neuter animals (i.e., remove their testicles) rather than performing a vasectomy (i.e., cutting the vas deferens to block the flow of sperm). 
First, a vasectomy is a more complicated and invasive surgery than neutering. It requires a higher level of surgical skill and specialized equipment, and the recovery period is typically longer for the animal. In contrast, neutering is a relatively straightforward procedure that can often be performed under general anesthesia in a veterinary clinic setting. 
Second, neutering is more effective at reducing unwanted behaviors in animals, such as aggression, marking territory, and roaming. This is because neutering removes the source of hormones (testosterone) that contribute to these behaviors. A vasectomy, on the other hand, only blocks the flow of sperm and does not significantly reduce the production of hormones. 
Finally, neutering is a more cost-effective option for pet owners, as it is generally less expensive than a vasectomy. 
Overall, while a vasectomy might seem more humane in theory, in practice it is usually a less practical and effective option for preventing unwanted pregnancies and modifying behavior in animals.

question: Why do we have both a North and a True North ? My iPhone shows if I want to see the North or the True North . What is the difference between both and why do both exist ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Great question! The Earth is not a perfect sphere, it is actually slightly flattened at the poles and bulges at the equator. This means that the Earth's rotational axis, which is an imaginary line that runs through the center of the Earth and around which the Earth rotates, is not perpendicular to the surface of the Earth. Instead, it is tilted by about 23.5 degrees. 
The North Pole is the point on the Earth's surface that is directly above the Earth's rotational axis. This is the point that is used to define the direction of "north." 
True North, on the other hand, is the direction of the North Pole relative to the surface of the Earth. It is the direction that a compass needle points towards, which is not the same as the direction of the North Pole. This is because the Earth's magnetic field causes the compass needle to be attracted to the Earth's magnetic north pole, which is not exactly the same as the Earth's rotational north pole. 
So, to sum it up: "North" is the direction that is defined by the Earth's rotational axis, and "True North" is the direction that a compass needle points towards due to the Earth's magnetic field. Both of these directions are important for different reasons, and that's why we have both of them.

question: How and why did Global Warming get changed to Climate Change ? Climate change always seemed so generic , since our climate is always changing . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Global warming and climate change are often used interchangeably, but they refer to slightly different things. 
Global warming refers to the increase in the average temperature of the Earth's atmosphere, especially at the surface, which has been occurring over the past century or so. The main cause of global warming is the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal and oil, which releases greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. These gases trap heat from the sun and cause the Earth's temperature to rise. 
Climate change, on the other hand, refers to the broader range of changes that are occurring in the Earth's climate, including not only the increase in temperature, but also changes in precipitation patterns, sea level, and other factors. Climate change can be caused by both natural and human factors, and it can have a range of impacts on the environment, including more frequent heatwaves, droughts, and extreme weather events like hurricanes and floods. 
So, to sum it up, global warming is a specific aspect of climate change, which is a broader term that encompasses a range of changes that are occurring in the Earth's climate.

question: Why do cars only have defroster grids in the rear window ? I am thinking it has something to do with what might happen if the windshield shattered , but it would be convenient a lot of the time . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Cars only have defroster grids in the rear window because the front windshield is made of different material than the rear window. The front windshield is made of laminated safety glass, which is two layers of glass with a plastic layer in between. The laminated safety glass is designed to stay in one piece even if it cracks or breaks, so it doesn't need a defroster grid to help clear it. 
The rear window, on the other hand, is usually made of tempered glass, which is a type of glass that shatters into small pieces if it breaks. Tempered glass is used in the rear window because it is stronger and more durable than regular glass, but it is also more prone to fogging up or getting covered in condensation. That's why the rear window has a defroster grid, which is a grid of heating elements that help clear the window of fog or condensation. 
So, in short, cars have defroster grids in the rear window because it is made of a different type of glass that is more prone to fogging up, and because the front windshield is made of laminated safety glass that doesn't need a defroster grid.

question: When I need to pee , and I 'm standing there waiting , but nothing is coming out , what 's happening in my body that 's making me wait ? Shy pissers unite ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer: You brain is good at knowing when the appropriate time to " go " is , so much so that it lets you be largely in charge of it . This happens because of 4 different types of nerves controlling the urinary mechanisms : Sensory ( afferent ) nerves , which tell you your bladder is full ; sympathetic ( " fight / flight " ) nerves which relax the bladder and keep the urinary sphincter tight ; parasympathetic ( " rest / digest " ) nerves which contract the bladder and relax said sphincter ; and somatic nerves ( that act on skeletal muscles , i.e. Muscles you can control voluntarily ) which let you initiate when to go . When you are in line at Fatty 's Pizza Shack , for instance , your sympathetic nervous system ( fight / flight ) is keeping that bladder sphincter tightly closed ( it does this without you even knowing it , much like you do n't need to consciously make your heart beat ) . Later , after drinking your extra large Floaty Shake , your bladder fills with urine , and sensory nerves alert you to this fact via stretch receptors on the bladder itself . As your bladder fills with more urine , the stretch sensors cause little contractions in the bladder which you feel as urges . When you finally feel like it 's a good time to pee on something , your somatic nerves signal your accessory muscles ( abdominals ) to assist with voiding ( a fancy word for micturition which is an even fancier word for urination ) , and your parasympathetic nerves ( rest / digest ) takes the hint and squeezes the bladder and relaxes your urinary sphincter . The result is pee happening . Several regions in the brain are also involved , mainly keeping you from peeing when you do n't want to pee . You can consciously keep from wetting yourself for quite a while , unless you have some sort of disease where nerves are damaged or the muscles in your bladder ( detrusor muscle and sphincters ) do n't cooperate . Incontinence = ca n't hold it in . Enuresis = bedwetting .

question: When I need to pee , and I 'm standing there waiting , but nothing is coming out , what 's happening in my body that 's making me wait ? Shy pissers unite ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
When you feel the urge to urinate, your body is sending a signal to your brain that your bladder is full and needs to be emptied. The bladder is a muscular sac in your pelvis that stores urine until it is ready to be expelled from the body. 
When you stand at the toilet and try to urinate, your brain sends a signal to the muscles in your pelvic area to relax, including the muscles that control the bladder. At the same time, the muscles in the wall of your bladder contract, pushing the urine out through the urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body). 
Sometimes, when you try to urinate, the muscles in your pelvic area may not fully relax, or the muscles in the wall of your bladder may not contract strongly enough. This can make it difficult to start urinating, or to urinate as much as you normally would. This is more common in men, but it can happen to anyone. 
There are a few things you can try to help you urinate more easily when you're having difficulty: 
1. Take a deep breath and try to relax your muscles. 
2. Try massaging your lower abdomen or stomach area gently. 
3. Drink a glass of water or another fluid. This can help to increase the volume of urine in your bladder, making it easier to start urinating. 
4. Try going back to bed and waiting a little while longer. Sometimes, just waiting a few minutes can help your muscles relax enough to allow you to urinate. 
If you continue to have difficulty urinating, or if you have other symptoms such as pain or blood in your urine, you should speak with a healthcare provider. They can help to determine the cause of your symptoms and provide treatment if necessary.

question: Difference between isopropyl alcohol ( " rubbing alcohol " ) , ethyl alcohol , and methyl alcohol ? Edit : Thanks guys . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Isopropyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol, and methyl alcohol are all types of alcohol, but they have some differences. 
Isopropyl alcohol, also known as rubbing alcohol, is a type of alcohol that is commonly used as a disinfectant. It is a clear, colorless liquid with a strong, sweet smell. It is often used to clean surfaces and to kill germs on the skin. 
Ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol or grain alcohol, is a type of alcohol that is commonly found in alcoholic beverages like beer, wine, and liquor. It is also used as a solvent and in the production of personal care and cleaning products. Ethyl alcohol is a clear, colorless liquid with a sweet, fruity smell. 
Methyl alcohol, also known as methanol or wood alcohol, is a type of alcohol that is toxic and not suitable for consumption. It is sometimes used as an industrial solvent and in the production of chemicals. Methyl alcohol is a clear, colorless liquid with a strong, sweet smell. 
In summary, isopropyl alcohol is a type of alcohol that is used as a disinfectant, ethyl alcohol is a type of alcohol found in alcoholic beverages, and methyl alcohol is a toxic alcohol that is not suitable for consumption.

question: Sugar , is it worse for your teeth to have alot of sugar in one go or to spread it out over time ? Is there a limit to how much damage you can do to your teeth with sugar in one go ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
It's generally better for your teeth to have sugar in small amounts rather than all at once. That's because sugar can cause tooth decay, which is a process that happens when bacteria in your mouth use sugar from the foods you eat to make acids. These acids can attack your tooth enamel, which is the hard outer layer of your teeth. If the enamel gets weak or wears away, it can lead to cavities. 
When you eat or drink something with sugar in it, the bacteria in your mouth start making acid right away. The more sugar you eat or drink, the more acid they can make. So if you eat or drink a lot of sugar all at once, your teeth will be exposed to a lot of acid at once, which can be harmful. 
On the other hand, if you have small amounts of sugar throughout the day, your teeth will be exposed to acid for a longer period of time, but the amount of acid they're exposed to at any given moment will be smaller. This can be less harmful to your teeth. 
It's also important to remember to brush your teeth twice a day and floss once a day to help remove sugar and plaque from your teeth. Plaque is a sticky film of bacteria that can build up on your teeth and cause tooth decay. 
So, to sum up: it's better for your teeth to have sugar in small amounts rather than all at once, and it's important to brush and floss your teeth to help protect them from sugar and plaque.

So when you see 1.2W = 10W on an LED lightbulb, it means that the LED bulb uses 1.2 watts of electricity to produce the same amount of light as a traditional incandescent bulb that uses 10 watts of electricity. question: How is a place like Chernobyl uninhabitable due to radiation but Hiroshima is fine . What was the difference between the radiation in the two instances ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer: There are a few of things that make Chernobyl still far more radioactive than Hiroshima and Nagasaki . First , the bombs actually did n't use very much radioactive material , all things considered . A nuclear reactor consumes much greater quantities of fuel than does a bomb , since the bomb is made to go BOOM and then be done with while the reactor needs a long , energetic , sustained reaction . Second , the fissile material in the atomic bombs was vaporized . I do n't mean that it disappeared , completely , but I mean was turned into plasma in the explosion . This pushed it much higher in the atmosphere and spread out the material over a huge distance . Without large concentrations , what little radioactive decay takes place over time ( remember that U235 and P239 have fairly long half lives and do n't release a ton of highly energetic particles when they do decay ) quickly became nominal compared to the standard background radiation . Third , very little of the fuel actually turned into the more dangerous radioactive intermediates . The percentages of the fuel actually consumed in those bombs is minute - more modern nuclear weaponry may leave longer lasting radiation . So that 's what happened in the bomb areas - Big releases of radiation at the time of explosion , but not much retained in the soil and region afterwards . In Chernobyl , on the other hand , large quantities of highly radioactive material were released into the atmosphere because of the heat from the fire generated . This includes radioactive steams ( heavy water ) , irradiated metals , intermediates , large quantities of spent and active fuels , the works . These were concentrated on the town , and were n't largely consumed in a big nuclear boom - most of those materials do n't actually go boom either . As a result of the varying half lives and the extremely large quantities of material in the area , it 's still very radioactive , especially near the core which got a logarithmically greater dose than the surrounding areas .

question: How is a place like Chernobyl uninhabitable due to radiation but Hiroshima is fine . What was the difference between the radiation in the two instances ? Please explain like I'm five.

Chernobyl was the site of a nuclear power plant disaster in 1986. A reactor at the plant exploded, releasing a huge amount of radiation into the environment. This radiation made the area around the plant unsafe for people to live in for a long time. 
Hiroshima, on the other hand, was the site of an atomic bomb explosion during World War II. While the bomb did release a lot of radiation, it was only released for a very short period of time. The radiation levels in Hiroshima returned to normal relatively quickly, so people were able to go back and live there again. 
The main difference between the two is the amount and duration of radiation released. In Chernobyl, the radiation was released over a longer period of time and covered a larger area, making it unsafe for people to live there. question: Why are the police so reluctant to use body cameras ? Would n't it protect them from false accusations ? I know financially , adding body cams force wide would be taxing , but what other negative implications could it possible serve ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
There are a few reasons why police departments might be reluctant to use body cameras. One reason is the cost of purchasing and maintaining the cameras and the associated technology. Body cameras and the infrastructure needed to support them can be expensive, and some police departments may not have the budget to implement a body camera program. 
Another reason is the potential for privacy concerns. Body cameras record video and audio of everything that happens while they are turned on, and this can include personal conversations and interactions that might be considered private. There are also concerns about how the footage will be stored and who will have access to it. 
Finally, there may be logistical challenges to using body cameras, such as deciding when they should be turned on and off and how to handle footage that is recorded during sensitive or confidential situations. 
Overall, while body cameras can provide protection for police officers by providing a record of their interactions with the public, there are also potential costs and challenges associated with their use.

question: If cancer is just cells mutating and dividing without abandon , how does it cause the " rot " we see in later stages ? Title . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: The cancerous " rot " you show below is a result of necrosis where the tumor has grown so much that it no longer get nutrients and oxygen from the blood supply . The cells on the interior of the tumor die . There are two types of cell death : apopotosis , which is tightly regulated , and necrosis , which is unregulated . Unregulated dying , as is the case in tumor rot , causes a cell to release all of its contents onto neighboring cells , causing those cells to necrose as well . This usually results in the entire area to start decomposing , causing secondary bacterial infections and general gross - ness . This is part of the reason why people with necrotising fasciitis ( flesh eating disease ) have to get entire areas of necrosis removed , like arms or legs or whatever to prevent the rot from spreading . Fortunately , in humans cancer rarely gets so bad that you see that extent of rot . Usually the tumor is palpable and can be treated or removed before huge rotting occurs . Source : PhD in cancer metabolism .

question: If cancer is just cells mutating and dividing without abandon , how does it cause the " rot " we see in later stages ? Title . Please explain like I'm five.

Cancer is a group of diseases that are characterized by the uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells in the body. When normal cells divide and grow, they follow a specific pattern that helps the body function properly. But when cancer cells develop, they don't follow this pattern and can grow out of control, forming a mass of tissue called a tumor. 
Cancer cells can also spread to other parts of the body, where they can grow and form new tumors. This is called metastasis. When cancer cells spread to other parts of the body, they can interfere with the normal functioning of those organs and tissues, which can cause a variety of symptoms and complications. 
As cancer cells grow and divide, they can interfere with the normal functioning of the body's tissues and organs. For example, a tumor in the lung may make it difficult for a person to breathe. A tumor in the stomach may cause a person to feel full and have trouble eating. And a tumor in the brain may cause a person to experience headaches and changes in their thinking or behavior. 
In the later stages of cancer, the tumors may become very large and may begin to interfere with the body's vital functions, such as the ability to breathe or pump blood. The cancer may also spread to other parts of the body, which can lead to additional symptoms and complications. 
Cancer can also weaken the body's immune system, making it more difficult for the body to fight off infections and other diseases. This can make a person more susceptible to getting sick and may cause additional complications.

question: Why do humans have different bloodtypes ? URL_0 This was interesting Please explain like I'm five.
answer: If you 're looking for the anatomical reason , it deals with the Red Blood Cell surfaces . RBCs are the cells that contain hemoglobin , which act to pick up / drop Oxygen and Carbon Dioxide in the blood stream to metabolically support and " feed " all of the cells in your body . An antigen is a protein on the surface of a cell that acts as a " flag " for the immune system . RBCs in a certain person contain contain types of antigens . In reality , there are thousands of antigens present , but in terms of labeling RBCs , there are 3 important ones : A , B , and D ( Rh ) . A person with a certain antigen of these three would also have blood plasma ( surrounding liquid around RBCs ) containing antibodies ( bind to the antigens ) for the other blood types . For example , a person with Type A blood would have antigens for Type B and D Blood . This is why you ca n't give blood to a person of a different blood type because the antibodies will react with your antigens on your RBCs , causing clumping and apoptosis . The Rh antigen brings the + /- factor that you often see on blood types . If Rh ( D ) is present , the type is + and the plasma contains no Rh antibodies . If Rh is not present on the surface , the type is - and the plasma contains Rh antibodies . Effectively , these are the blood types : A+ : contains A , D antigens and B antibodies A- : contains A antigens and B , D antibodies B+ : contains B , D antigens and A antibodies B- : contains B antigens and A , D antibodies AB+ : contains A , B , D antigens and no antibodies AB- : contains A , B antigens and D antibodies O+ : contains D antigens , and A , B antibodies O- : contains no antigens , and A , B , D antibodies This would make O- the universal donor blood type because the blood cells contain no antigens for which a recipient 's antibodies could react with . AB+ is the universal recipient because it has no antibodies in the plasma that could react with a donor 's blood 's antigens .

question: Why do humans have different bloodtypes ? URL_0 This was interesting Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Sure! The different blood types in humans are determined by proteins called antigens that are found on the surface of red blood cells. There are two main antigens: A and B. People can have either A, B, both A and B, or neither A and B. 
If a person has the A antigen on their red blood cells, they are said to have type A blood. If they have the B antigen, they have type B blood. If they have both A and B antigens, they have type AB blood. And if they don't have either A or B antigens, they have type O blood. 
The different blood types are important because they can affect whether or not a person can receive certain types of blood transfusions. For example, if a person with type A blood receives a transfusion of type B blood, their body may react to the B antigens and cause serious problems. This is why it's important to match the blood type of the donor and the recipient when giving a blood transfusion.

AM and FM are separate methods of encoding and broadcasting radio signals . M works by modulating the amplitude of the signal according to the information being sent , while the frequency remains constant . This differs from FM technology in which sound is encoded by varying the frequency of the wave and the amplitude is kept constant . . question: Why do AM and FM radio signals sound so different ? A show I listen to on FM in the afternoons replays the next morning on AM , why does the AM station sound so much different ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
AM and FM radio signals sound different because they use different methods to transmit information. AM stands for "amplitude modulation," and FM stands for "frequency modulation." 
In AM radio, the strength or amplitude of the radio signal is used to carry the information, such as music or speech. The signal is sent out at a specific frequency, and the amplitude (or strength) of the signal is changed to transmit the information. 
In FM radio, the frequency of the radio signal is used to carry the information. The signal is sent out at a specific frequency, and the frequency of the signal is changed slightly to transmit the information. 
Because AM radio uses changes in the amplitude of the signal to transmit information, it can be more prone to interference from things like electrical storms or other sources of interference. This can make the sound quality of AM radio less clear than FM radio. FM radio, on the other hand, uses changes in the frequency of the signal to transmit information, which makes it less prone to interference and generally gives it better sound quality.

question: Lucid Dreaming and how do I train myself ? Is it a skill that can be taught ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Lucid dreaming is a type of dream where you are aware that you are dreaming and can sometimes even control what happens in the dream. Some people believe that it is possible to train yourself to have lucid dreams, and there are a few different techniques that you can try to increase your chances of having one. 
One way to train yourself to have a lucid dream is to keep a dream journal. Every morning after you wake up, write down everything you can remember about your dreams from the night before. This can help you become more aware of your dreams and may increase your chances of having a lucid dream. 
Another technique is to do something called "reality checking." This means that you regularly check during the day to see if you are awake or dreaming. For example, you can try to push your finger through your palm or look at a clock and then look away and look back to see if the time has changed. If you do this enough, you may start doing it in your dreams and realize that you are dreaming. 
There are also some other techniques that you can try, such as setting an intention to have a lucid dream before you go to sleep, or trying to stay as awake as possible just before you fall asleep. 
Overall, whether or not it is possible to train yourself to have lucid dreams is still a topic of debate, and different people may have different experiences. However, if you are interested in trying to have a lucid dream, it can be fun to experiment with different techniques and see what works for you.

question: Why infrared thermometers measure a mirror 's surface , and not the surface it is reflected on . In the title . Please explain like I'm five.

When an infrared thermometer is pointed at a mirror, the sensor in the thermometer detects the infrared radiation emitted by the surface of the mirror. This is because the mirror is reflecting the infrared radiation emitted by the object that the mirror is facing, so the sensor in the thermometer is able to detect the radiation coming from the surface of the mirror. 
It's important to note that the infrared thermometer is not measuring the temperature of the object that the mirror is reflecting. Instead, it is measuring the temperature of the surface of the mirror itself. This is why an infrared thermometer will measure the temperature of a mirror's surface, rather than the surface that the mirror is reflecting.

question: How do VHS tapes play audio ? I understand how they play video somewhat . However , how does a VHS tape play audio ? Thanks . ( Explained ) Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
VHS tapes, also known as VHS cassette tapes, are a type of magnetic tape that was commonly used for recording and playing back video and audio in the 20th century. They work by using a magnetic head to read and write magnetic signals on the tape. 
When you insert a VHS tape into a VHS player, the player's drive motor moves the tape past a series of spinning heads. These heads are magnetically charged and can read the magnetic signals on the tape. As the tape moves past the heads, the signals are converted into an electrical current, which is then amplified and played through the speakers of the VHS player. 
The audio on a VHS tape is typically recorded in a format called "analog audio," which means that the audio is stored as a continuous, wave-like signal on the tape. This is different from "digital audio," which stores audio as a series of 1s and 0s. When you play a VHS tape, the audio is read from the tape and converted into sound waves that you can hear through the speakers.

question: How do microphones not repeat what it " hears " from the speakers ? For example if you are on a skype call how does the microphone differentiate the sound of your voice from the voice of the person you are calling ? Please explain like I'm five.

When you are on a Skype call and you speak into your microphone, the microphone converts the sound waves of your voice into an electrical signal. This electrical signal is then sent through a wire (or wirelessly, if you are using a wireless microphone) to the computer or other device you are using for the Skype call. The computer processes the electrical signal and converts it back into sound waves, which are then played through the speakers for the other person on the call to hear. 
At the same time, the other person's voice is also being captured by their microphone and converted into an electrical signal, which is sent to your computer. Your computer processes this electrical signal and plays the sound waves through your speakers so that you can hear the other person. 
The microphone and the speakers are connected to different parts of the computer or device, so they do not interfere with each other. The microphone is able to pick up sound waves from your voice, but it is not able to pick up the sound waves that are being played through the speakers. Similarly, the speakers are able to play sound waves that are being sent to them, but they do not interfere with the microphone's ability to pick up sound waves. This is why you are able to have a conversation on Skype without the microphone repeating what it hears through the speakers.

question: Why does it suddenly feel like our hearts drop everytime we see or do something startling like a teacher calling us over to their desk ? Admit it , you got scared whenever a teacher called you over . Please explain like I'm five.

When we see or do something startling or unexpected, our bodies often respond with a physical reaction called the "fight or flight" response. This is a natural instinct that helps us prepare to either fight or run away from a perceived threat. 
During the fight or flight response, our bodies release a hormone called adrenaline, which increases our heart rate and blood pressure. This can make our heart feel like it is racing or "dropping," and can also cause us to feel scared or anxious. 
Sometimes, when a teacher calls us over to their desk, we may not know what to expect and our brains may perceive this as a potential threat. This can trigger the fight or flight response and cause us to feel scared or anxious. 
It's important to remember that these physical reactions are normal and can help us prepare to handle unexpected situations. However, if we feel scared or anxious a lot of the time, it might be helpful to talk to a trusted adult or a mental health professional for support.

question: What Happens In Your Body The Exact Moment You Fall Asleep ? Wow Guys , thanks for all your answers ! ! ! ! I learned so much today ! Please explain like I'm five.
answer: See , you do n't actually fall asleep all at once . It 's more of a well - defined process that everyone makes their way through in their own time . I 'll attempt to explain it . ----------------------------------------------------------------------- You start off moving into what 's called Stage 1 , from being completely awake . When you first lay down to go to sleep , you pass from your awake state to what 's called Alpha state . You 've daydreamed before , right ? That 's basically Alpha state . You 're still mostly conscious , but you start to see some little bouts of color behind your eyes ( hypnogogic hallucinations ) and you start to feel more relaxed . After Alpha , you enter Theta state . Theta state is when you could technically be considered asleep . This is when you move completely into sleep paralysis ( have you felt like you were falling then woken up with a start ? that 's sleep paralysis setting in and you not being completely unaware when it happened ) . You 're still sleeping relatively lightly , but if you can get through this stage you move into deeper sleep . ----------------------------------------------------------------------- The next major stage of sleep is called Stage 2 . Your brain starts to produce short periods of rapid brain waves that are called Sleep Spindles . This is the precursor to what comes next in sleep , deep sleep . Your body temperature begins to drop and your heart rate slows down , settling you in for the night . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ You then enter Stage 3 . When you enter stage 3 , really slow brain waves called Delta waves start happening . This is the true transition between light and deep sleep . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ You then enter Stage 4 . Stage four is commonly referred to as Delta Sleep because of the brain waves associated with it . It 's a deep sleep that lasts for about thirty minutes . You are the technically the most asleep in this stage . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Here 's where it gets interesting . There is another stage of sleep unlike all the others . It 's called Stage 5 , or REM sleep . REM stands for Rapid Eye Movement , your eyes literally start moving rapidly behind your eyelids . Your breathing rate increases , and your brain waves shoot up to almost as active as if you were awake . Your voluntary muscles become completely paralyzed , and you start dreaming . REM is also where most of the body 's repairs happen . REM sleep is what makes you feel rested when you wake up , and where the body actually rests and restores itself ( which is why you usually do n't feel rested after a night of drinking or smoking weed , they both inhibit REM sleep ) . ----------------------------------------------------------------------- These stages come in cycles . It takes roughly 90 minutes for you to go from awake into REM . The first cycle typically has a short REM period , but subsequent cycles increase the duration of REM . When we actually fall asleep , we go from stage 1 into 2 , then 3 , then 4 , but here 's where something curious happens . We then go from 4 to 3 , then 3 to 2 , then into REM . After REM , we usually return to stage 2 , then go back to 3 , 4 , then 3 , 2 , REM . We have as many cycles as we stay asleep for , when we wake up , feeling refreshed and ready or the day . ------------------------------------------------------------------------ I do n't know if that answered your question , but I hope it shed some light on the subject . Edit : formatting . Edit 2 : I 'll be here if anyone has any other questions they 'd like answered about this topic . Edit 3 : Holy crap ! Thanks for popping my gold cherry anon ! Much love ! < 3 Edit 4 : Wow this blew up ... Thanks for all the questions ! I 'm getting to them all , do n't worry !

question: What Happens In Your Body The Exact Moment You Fall Asleep ? Wow Guys , thanks for all your answers ! ! ! ! I learned so much today ! Please explain like I'm five.

When you fall asleep, your body goes through a series of changes. Here's what happens: 
1. Your muscles start to relax: As you start to fall asleep, your muscles begin to relax, especially in your face, neck, and limbs. You might notice that your arms and legs feel heavy and you might feel a tingling sensation in your hands and feet. 
2. Your breathing and heart rate slow down: As you fall deeper into sleep, your breathing and heart rate slow down. You might notice that your breaths become slower and deeper, and your heart rate becomes more regular. 
3. Your brain waves change: There are different types of brain waves, and the type of brain wave you have depends on what you're doing. When you're awake, your brain waves are fast and active. But as you fall asleep, your brain waves slow down and become more regular. 
4. Your body temperature drops: As you fall asleep, your body temperature drops slightly. This is why you might feel cold when you first go to bed, but then warm up as you fall asleep. 
5. Your body enters different stages of sleep: There are two main types of sleep: REM (rapid eye movement) sleep and non-REM sleep. Non-REM sleep is divided into three stages: light sleep, deep sleep, and very deep sleep. As you fall asleep, you move through these stages of sleep in a cycle that lasts about 90 minutes.

question: How are No - Knock Warrants Legal in the US ? Between [ this incorporation in the 4th Amendment ] ( URL_1 ) and [ this Supreme Court Ruling ] ( URL_0 ) , how are No - Knock warrants legal in the United States ? Please explain like I'm five.

No-knock warrants are warrants that allow law enforcement officers to enter a property without first announcing their presence or purpose. In the United States, the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution protects citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures by the government. This means that law enforcement officers generally need a warrant to search a person's home or property, and they must follow certain procedures when doing so. 
One of these procedures is the "knock and announce" rule, which requires officers to announce their presence and purpose before entering a property. However, in some cases, officers may be able to get a no-knock warrant, which allows them to enter a property without first announcing their presence. 
No-knock warrants are generally only granted in cases where there is a risk of danger to the officers or the public, or a risk that evidence might be destroyed if the officers announce their presence. In order to get a no-knock warrant, law enforcement officers must provide a judge with evidence that there is a good reason to bypass the knock and announce rule. 
The Supreme Court has ruled that no-knock warrants are constitutional as long as they are used in a reasonable manner. This means that officers must have a good reason for using a no-knock warrant, and they must follow all other rules and procedures when executing the warrant. However, there have been cases where no-knock warrants have been used improperly, leading to controversy and calls for reform.

question: Why is the letter " W " pronounced " double - u " when " double - v " would seem to be more accurate ? Also , " W " is the only letter in the alphabet with more than one syllable . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: This goes back to the time when U and V were actually the same letter ; so , in fact , were I and J. This is what the classical Latin alphabet looked like : A B C D E F G H I K L M N O P Q R S T V X Y Z But in handwriting , it looked a bit more like this : * a b c d e f g h j k l m n o p q r s t u x y z * Notice that in the capital letters , there is no J or U ; and in the cursive letters , no * i * or * v * . Instead , you had the following capital / cursive pairs : I*j * and V*u * . So the name " Julius " would , in Latin , be carved in stone as " IVLIVS " , but written by hand as " * juljus * " . These letters could be used as vowels or consonants ; so the letter " I " as a vowel had a sound like the " i " in " sit " , and as a consonant a sound like the " y " in " yes " ; the letter " V " had as a vowel a sound like the " u " in " put " , and as a consonant ... well , it was either like our " w " , or like our " v " . The smart money is on " w " , but there were no tape recorders in those days so we ca n't be sure . But a word like " * uacuum * " might have been pronounced " wack - woom " , and explains why our word " vacuum " has two Us in it . The phrase " * uenj ujdj ujcj * " , which we usually spell " veni vidi vici " ( " I came , I saw , I conquered " ) might have been pronounced " wenny weedy weeky " or " wenny weedy wee - chee " ( again , we ca n't be sure ) . When the Roman alphabet was used to write other languages , those other languages often had sounds that did n't exist in Latin . Sometimes they added extra letters ( for example , the letters Ð and Þ , which are still used in modern Icelandic ) , sometimes they put two or more letters together to make a new sound ( for example , our TH ) . For some languages , a new letter was created by doubling the letter V -- so VV ; or , in cursive , * uu * . Hence the name , " double - U " . But additionally , the letters I and V were " split " , to make two versions of each -- originally , one for the vowel and one for the consonant . So the letter I*j * was split to make Ii for the vowel and Jj for the consonant ( which in modern English is now pronounced differently -- in modern German it 's still pronounced like our Y ) ; V*u * was similarly split to make Uu ( vowel ) and Vv ( consonant ) . The W took on the form of the V , but we kept the name " double - U " . This is actually appropriate , because the English " w " sound is , in effect , a very short " u " sound . Languages like French did n't originally have this letter , because it was n't needed -- except for writing foreign words , like " le weekend " . But since the W now looks like two Vs , the French called it " double - V " . Incidentally , although you might not think it , the sounds of " W " and " V " are , phonetically , very closely related . Native English speakers can hear the difference so clearly they do n't realise how similar they are ; many Germans , however , find it very difficult , and often confuse the sounds , saying " wiolin " instead of " violin " , for example . Both sounds are also very closely related to " U " .

One reason for this is that the letter "V" and the letter "W" have very different histories and origins. The letter "V" comes from the Latin letter "V," which was used to represent the sound "v." question: How is it possible for the hadron collider to reach a temperature of close to 1 trillion degrees without burning a hole through our planet ? Just saw the TIL about this and have no idea what it means Please explain like I'm five.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is a particle accelerator, not a heat source. It is designed to collide particles together at very high energies, but these collisions do not produce heat in the way that burning a piece of wood does. Instead, the energy of the collisions is converted into other forms of energy, such as the kinetic energy of the particles that are produced in the collision or the energy of new particles that are created. 
To understand how the LHC works, it helps to think about a simpler example: two cars colliding head-on at high speed. When the cars collide, they transfer their kinetic energy (the energy they have due to their motion) to each other. This energy can be converted into other forms of energy, such as the sound of the collision or the heat that is produced as the cars deform and the materials they are made of stretch and break. 
Similarly, when particles collide in the LHC, they transfer their energy to each other, and this energy can be converted into various forms. The LHC is designed to produce very high-energy collisions, but the energy of the collisions is spread out over a very small volume, so it does not produce a significant amount of heat.

There are several benefits to being able to move our eyes together. For one, it allows us to have better depth perception, which is the ability to judge the distance of objects from us. Instead, they use the top-level domains (TLDs) ".co.uk" and ".com.au," respectively. The TLDs ".co.uk" and ".com.au" are used to indicate the country where a website is registered or based. question: If x^2 derived is 2x , why is n't sin^2 x derived = 2 sin x. Same goes for the integral / antiderivatives where integral of x is x^2/2 . But not for sin / cos . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: The chain rule . When you write sin^2 x ( a convenient notation ) as ( sin x)^2 the derivative is 2(sin x ) times the derivative of what is inside , which is cos x. So the derivative is 2(sin x)(cos x ) . We can actually use the chain rule in the derivative of x^2 but it 's sort of hidden . Write x^2 as ( x)^2 which has derivative 2x times the derivative of what is inside , which is 1 , but anything times 1 is itself so the derivative is just 2x . In general , the derivative of any differentiable function of the form f(g(x ) ) is f'(g(x))g'(x ) where f ' and g ' are the respective derivatives of f and g , and this is the chain rule . In your example , f(x)=x^2 and g(x)=sin x. Antiderivatives are more complicated because while it is easy to apply the chain rule in one direction ( derivatives ) , it is not so easy to go backwards ( antiderivatives ) . Sometimes u substitution works but not always .

question: If x^2 derived is 2x , why is n't sin^2 x derived = 2 sin x. Same goes for the integral / antiderivatives where integral of x is x^2/2 . But not for sin / cos . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Derivatives and integrals are operations that allow us to find the rate of change of a function or the area under a curve, respectively. The derivative of a function tells us how the function is changing at any given point, and the integral of a function gives us the total amount that the function has changed over a certain interval. 
The derivative of x^2 is 2x because x^2 is increasing at a rate of 2x at every point. In other words, if x is increasing by a small amount, then x^2 is increasing by twice that amount. This relationship is captured by the derivative of x^2, which is 2x. 
The derivative of sin^2 x, on the other hand, is not equal to 2 sin x. The derivative of sin^2 x is actually 2 sin x cos x. This is because sin^2 x is not increasing at a constant rate like x^2. Instead, the rate at which sin^2 x is increasing depends on the value of sin x and cos x at that point. When sin x is large and cos x is small, sin^2 x is increasing quickly. When sin x is small and cos x is large, sin^2 x is increasing more slowly. The derivative of sin^2 x takes this changing rate of change into account. 
Similarly, the integral of x is x^2/2 because the total amount that x has changed over a certain interval can be represented by the area of a rectangle with base x and height x/2. The integral of sin x or cos x, on the other hand, cannot be represented by a simple polynomial like x^2/2. Instead, these functions require more complex mathematical expressions to describe their total change over an interval.

question: How can our ribs " expand " ? Are the ribs completely static or can they expand somehow ? I 'd appreciate a thorough explanation on how the ribs interact with our organs and bodies . Please explain like I'm five.

Upper ribs move more vertically ( think of the sternum as a well pump handle [ URL_0 ] , but with ribs coming off of it . That is the plane of movement of these ribs . question: How can our ribs " expand " ? Are the ribs completely static or can they expand somehow ? I 'd appreciate a thorough explanation on how the ribs interact with our organs and bodies . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
The ribs are bones that are attached to the spine and help protect the organs in the chest, such as the heart and lungs. While the ribs are generally not able to move or expand on their own, they do move slightly when we breathe. 
When we inhale, or take a deep breath in, the muscles between the ribs, called the intercostal muscles, contract and pull the ribs upwards and outwards. This expands the chest cavity and creates more space for the lungs to fill with air. When we exhale, or breathe out, the intercostal muscles relax and the ribs return to their normal position. 
So, while the ribs themselves do not expand, the chest cavity can expand and contract when we breathe, which can make it seem like the ribs are expanding. This is an important part of the process of breathing and helps us get the oxygen we need to survive.

question: Why race car tires have more traction without treads but consumer tires have more traction with treads . Uh , see title . Please explain like I'm five.
answer: Not including the compound of the rubber ( race ties being softer , and usually of a different chemical makeup ) , the difference comes down to water and heat cycles . Race tires without treads make the most contact , but they are used only in the dry . Consumer tires have to handle multiple conditions , including water . The treads channel water away from the tires surface , allowing the tire to make contact with the road instead of floating on top of the water . Consumer tires have far less traction when " bald " usually due to heat cycling , and the fact the the compound at that level is often different than the compound at the surface when a tire is newer . Heat cycling is essentially the hardening of the rubber each time the tire warms up and cools down . The harder the tire , the less grip . Many racers that are restricted to " street " tires will often shave tread off of brand new tires to reduce the amount of tread " squirm " and often get to a different compound ( if the tire is molded in such a way ) .

question: Why race car tires have more traction without treads but consumer tires have more traction with treads . Uh , see title . Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Race car tires are designed to provide maximum grip and traction on a racetrack. They are made of a special rubber compound that is very sticky and helps the tires adhere to the track surface. In addition, race car tires are generally very smooth and have no treads. This is because treads can actually reduce grip on a smooth surface like a racetrack. 
On the other hand, consumer tires are designed to be used on the road and are therefore built to handle a variety of surfaces and conditions. Treads on consumer tires help to provide grip on wet or slippery roads by channeling water away from the tire and increasing the tire's contact with the road. Treads also help to provide traction on loose or uneven surfaces, such as gravel or dirt roads. 
In summary, race car tires have more traction without treads because they are designed specifically for use on smooth, dry racetracks. Consumer tires have more traction with treads because they need to be able to handle a variety of road conditions, including wet and slippery surfaces.

question: What does it mean to refinance a house ? I know someone who is refinancing their house . He was telling me about it , but I really could n't follow . So what happens ? Please explain like I'm five.

They have certain terms , such as the interest rates and over how many years the loan has to be paid off . When you refinance you find a lender who loans you the money to pay off the original mortgage . You once again use your house as collateral for the new loan and now have a mortgage with a different lender . People refinance to get better terms on their mortgage . If your original mortgage has an interest rate of 6 % but you can get a new one with a 4 % interest rate you can save money by refinancing . Reasons you may be able to get a lower interest rate include better credit on your part ( maybe your credit score rose since you took out the original loan ) or a better lending environment ( federal interest rates are low so banks are generally giving lower interest loans ) .

question: What does it mean to refinance a house ? I know someone who is refinancing their house . He was telling me about it , but I really could n't follow . So what happens ? Please explain like I'm five.

Here's an example of how refinancing might work: 
Let's say that you have a mortgage on your home with an interest rate of 5%. You've been paying on this mortgage for a few years and have built up some equity in your home. Now, you find out that you can refinance your mortgage and get a new loan with an interest rate of 4%. Once you have been approved, the lender will pay off your old mortgage and give you a new loan with the lower interest rate. You will then make payments on this new loan instead of the old one. 
Overall, refinancing a house can be a good way to save money on your mortgage payments or to access the equity you have built up in your home. question: Why is there existence ? Why is there anything at all ? Deep thoughts .... Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
That's a very big and complex question that has puzzled philosophers, scientists, and thinkers for centuries. It's difficult to give a simple answer, but here is one way to think about it: 
Everything that exists has a cause or explanation for why it is the way it is. For example, if you have a pencil on your desk, you might wonder why it's there. The answer could be that someone put it there, or that you needed it for a task and got it out of a drawer. Either way, there is a reason or cause for why the pencil is on your desk. 
But when we try to think about the whole universe and everything in it, it becomes more difficult to find a cause or explanation. If we ask why the universe exists, we might try to find something or someone that caused it to exist. But then we have to ask what caused that thing or person, and so on. This can lead to an infinite loop, where we keep asking "why?" but never find a final answer. 
One possible way to think about the existence of the universe is that it simply exists, and there isn't necessarily a cause or explanation for why. This idea is sometimes called the "principle of sufficient reason," and it suggests that the universe doesn't need a cause because it is a fundamental aspect of reality. 
It's important to note that these are just some ways to think about the question of existence, and there is no one "right" answer. It's a topic that continues to be debated and explored by many people.

question: Why do we get milk / baby teeth then lose them ? It seems a bit redundant to grow a set of teeth then lose them just to grow another set back ? Are milk teeth different in terms of composition to your permanent teeth ? Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
Milk teeth, also known as baby teeth, are the first set of teeth that a child gets. These teeth are important because they help children learn to chew and speak properly, and they also hold space in the jaws for the permanent teeth that will come in later. 
Milk teeth are different from permanent teeth in a few ways. For one thing, they are smaller and more delicate than permanent teeth. They also have different shapes and are arranged differently in the mouth. Milk teeth also have thinner enamel, the hard outer layer that protects teeth, which makes them more prone to cavities. 
One of the reasons that children lose their milk teeth is because they are simply not strong enough to last a lifetime. They were only meant to be temporary, and once the permanent teeth start to come in, the milk teeth are no longer needed. The permanent teeth are much stronger and will be able to do a better job of chewing and biting food. 
So, in short, milk teeth are important for helping children learn to eat and speak, but they are eventually replaced by stronger, permanent teeth that are better able to do these tasks.

question: How do animals know who won a fight for dominance ? i 've always wondered how they know they have won without killing the other animal Please explain like I'm five.
answer: The victory for dominance comes when the an animal has established dominance over the other . Whenever the other animal feels powerless to continue , the dominating animal will psychologically feel being " in charge " . The other animal might feel " under control " , and thus he / she is n't dominative . How an animal " knows " who won the fight is how their minds make them feel . Dying is not necessary for this to happen , mere circumstances can be enough to induce these feelings . In battles of power , the classic psychological reactions are " fight " , " flight " and " freeze " . Flight and freeze automatically assert submission over the situation , as the animal feels that he / she is unable to fight and thus is n't dominative . Fight on the other hand implies dominance , and if both of the animals fight , whoever switches either to " flight " or " freeze " first loses dominance . Much of this happens also in the human world . For example , if you have a debate with someone , and you win by your arguments , then you may feel dominative . And conversely , if you lose , you may feel submissive .

question: How do animals know who won a fight for dominance ? i 've always wondered how they know they have won without killing the other animal Please explain like I'm five.
answer:
In many cases, animals can determine who has won a fight for dominance based on body language and other signals. For example, if one animal is clearly submitting to the other by lowering their head, averting their gaze, or making submissive noises, it may be clear to the other animal that they have won the fight. Similarly, if one animal is able to drive the other animal away or make them retreat, it may be clear that they have won the fight. 
It's also important to note that animals don't always have to fight to determine dominance. In some cases, they may use other forms of communication, such as vocalizations or gestures, to establish their dominance without physically engaging in a fight. 
In general, animals have developed a variety of ways to communicate with each other and establish social hierarchies, and they are often able to understand these signals and determine who has won a fight or other competition without resorting to lethal violence.
